j.  Any other item that could affect the proper function of the stormwater management system. 
(4)  Description of needed maintenance. 
(d)  After notification is provided to the owner of any deficiencies discovered from an inspection of a stormwater management system, the owner shall have 30 days or other time frame mutually agreed to between the IWC and the owner to correct the deficiencies. The IWC shall then conduct a subsequent inspection to ensure completion of the repairs. 
(e)  If repairs are not undertaken or are not done properly, then enforcement procedures of subsection 4-262(c) shall be followed by the IWC. 
(f)  If, after an inspection by the IWC the condition of a stormwater management facility presents an immediate danger to the public health or safety, because of an unsafe condition or improper maintenance, the IWC shall take such action as may be necessary to protect the public and make the facility safe. Any cost incurred by the Town of Seymour shall be assessed against the owner(s), as provided in subsection 4-262(c). 
(Ord. of 2-5-08(1), § 9.1) 
Sec. 4-262. - Maintenance agreement. 
(a)  Prior to the issuance of any building permit for which stormwater management is required, the IWC shall require the applicant or owner to execute an inspection and maintenance agreement binding on all subsequent owners of land served by a private stormwater management facility. Such agreement shall provide for access to the facility at reasonable times for regular inspections by the IWC or its authorized representative to ensure that the facility is maintained in proper working condition to meet design standards. 
(b)  The applicant and/or owner shall record the agreement in the land records of the town. 
(c)  The agreement shall also provide that, if after notice by the IWC its agent/s or the town engineer to correct a violation requiring maintenance work, satisfactory corrections are not made by the owner(s) within a reasonable period of time (30 days maximum), the IWC may perform all necessary work to place the facility in proper working condition. The owner(s) of the facility shall be assessed the cost of the work and any penalties. This may be accomplished by placing a lien on the property, which may be placed on the tax bill and collected as ordinary taxes by the town. 
(Ord. of 2-5-08(1), § 9.2) 
Sec. 4-263. - Maintenance responsibility. 
(a)  The owner of the property on which work has been done pursuant to this ordinance for private stormwater management facilities, or any other person or agent in control of such property, shall maintain in good condition and promptly repair and restore all grade surfaces, walls, drains, dams and structures, vegetation, erosion and sediment control measures, and other protective devices. Such repairs or restoration and maintenance shall be in accordance with approved plans. 
(b)  A maintenance schedule shall be developed for the life of any stormwater management facility and shall state the maintenance to be completed, the time period for completion, and who shall perform the maintenance. This maintenance schedule shall be printed on the approved stormwater management plan. 
(Ord. of 2-5-08(1), § 9.3) 
Chapter 4.5 - CIVIL SERVICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The Civil Service Ordinance of Sept. 6, 1994, Arts. I-XVI, has been included herein as a new Ch. 4.5, as herein set out, at the discretion of the editor. Minor changes have been made by the editor to provide consistency in numbering and style. Section catchlines have been largely provided by the editor. 
Charter reference- Board of library directors, § 5.1; civil service commissioner, § 10.3; town employees, § 11.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, § 2-1 et seq.; building inspector, § 4-26 et seq.; fire department, § 6-21 et seq.; housing code enforcement officer, § 9-61 et seq.; library, § 12-16 et seq.; sewer inspector, § 17-86 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - PURPOSE 

Sec. 4.5-1. - Civil service established. 
    There is hereby established a civil service system for the Town of Seymour. The civil service commission shall have such duties and responsibilities as are granted to it by Charter in section 10.3 and sections 11.1-11.3 of said Charter. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 1.01) 
Sec. 4.5-2. - Purpose. 
    It shall be the purpose of the civil service system to provide the means for selecting and/or promoting employees in the classified service solely on the basis of proven ability to perform the duties required as set forth by the specific job descriptions set forth in this ordinance. 
    It is hereby declared the personnel policy of the Town of Seymour that employment by the town in the classified service shall be based solely on merit and fitness, free of personal and political considerations. Appointments shall be based on systematic tests and evaluation. It is the desire of the town that high morals shall be maintained by the fair administration of the merit system established under this ordinance. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 1.02) 
Secs. 4.5-3-4.5-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 4.5-21. - Definitions of words and terms used in this chapter. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Appointing authority: The board of selectmen has the power and shall be the appointing authority for all civil service positions with the exception of the position of head librarian. With relation to the head librarian, the appointing authority shall be the library board of directors. 
    Civil service positions: The classified service positions shall be full time non-union employees of the Town of Seymour. The following will not be included within the classified service: 
(a)  Elective officials and persons appointed to fill vacancies in elective offices. 
(b)  Members of boards and other officers who are administrative appointments of the first selectman and the board of selectman unless otherwise provided by Charter. 
(c)  Employees of the board of education. 
(d)  Persons employed for a temporary or part time position. 
    Eligibility list: The eligibility list shall consist of those who have completed all elements of the testing procedure established by this ordinance. Said list shall include the applicant's name, final grade and rank. This list shall remain in effect for a period of one year. 
    Eligible person for positions: The candidates who rank the highest as recommended by the civil service commission shall be eligible for consideration and appointment to the position to be filled. The civil service commission shall present a list of such persons to the appointing authority for interview and appointment. 
    Full time employee: A full time employee shall be an employee who is employed in a civil service position as a permanent full time employee for 30 or more hours weekly. Any person who is permanently employed in one or more positions for a cumulative time of 30 hours or more hours will be considered full-time. 
    Any person holding a full time position in the municipal government as of June 1, 1984 shall be retained without preliminary or performance tests and shall thereafter be subject to all other respects to the provisions of this chapter. 
    Permanent employee: A permanent employee shall be an employee who successfully completes the probationary period and has been permanently appointed as provided in these policies and procedures. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 2.01-2.07) 
Secs. 4.5-21-4.5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE 

Sec. 4.5-31. - Applicability. 
    The following procedure applies to members of the classified service who have completed the probationary period. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.0) 
Sec. 4.5-32. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the grievance procedure shall be to settle employees' grievances on as low an administrative level as possible and practical so as to insure efficiency and employee morale. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.1) 
Sec. 4.5-33. - Grievance defined. 
    A grievance is defined as a dispute between an employee and/or the department head and the town, over the interpretation or application of a specific section in the civil service ordinance, Town Charter or regulations. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.2) 
Sec. 4.5-34. - Filing of grievances. 
    Grievances must be filed in writing within 14 calendar days of the incident giving rise to the grievance. All grievances shall be administered in accordance with the procedure set forth below. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.3) 
Sec. 4.5-35. - Representation by counsel. 
    An employee may be represented by counsel at each and every step of the grievance procedure. The employee shall bear the sole cost of the employment of said counsel. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.4) 
Sec. 4.5-36. - Working day defined for purposes of grievance procedure. 
    For the purpose of the grievance procedure, a working day is defined as Monday through Friday including holidays. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.5) 
Sec. 4.5-37. - Grievance procedure-Step 1. 
    An employee, or his or her legal counsel, if represented, may submit a written grievance in accordance with this section to the first selectman, or in his absence, to his designee and the appropriate department head. The first selectman, or said designee and the appropriate department head will make an effort to resolve the grievance and will render an answer in writing to the grievance within ten working days of receipt of the grievance. This answer will be provided to the aggrieved employee and to his counsel, if represented. In the case of the head librarian, the grievance will be submitted to the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.6) 
Sec. 4.5-38. - Same-Step 2. 
    If the aggrieved employee and the counsel is not satisfied with the decision rendered by the first selectman or his designee and the said department head, they may submit the grievance in writing to the full board of selectmen within seven working days of the decision. The full board of selectmen shall consider the grievance at its next scheduled meeting, which shall not be more than 15 days after the receipt of the grievance by the board of selectmen and shall render an answer to the grievance within seven working days after such scheduled meeting, to the aggrieved employee and his counsel, if represented. In the case of the head librarian, the second step of the grievance procedure shall be to the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.7) 
Sec. 4.5-39. - Same-Step 3. 
    If the aggrieved employee and his legal counsel, if represented, are not satisfied with the decision rendered by the board of selectmen (or library board of directors) they may appeal in writing to the full civil service commission, not later than ten calendar days after receipt of the decision of the board of selectmen (or library board of directors). The full civil service commission shall schedule a hearing with the aggrieved employee and his legal counsel, if represented, at the next scheduled meeting after receipt of the 
appeal. The full civil service commission will decide only one grievance per session. The full civil service commission shall make the final decision on the grievance after a full hearing. Such decision will be in writing and shall be made within ten working days of the hearing. The full civil service commission will hear both sides involved in the grievance. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 3.8) 
Secs. 4.5-40-4.5-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CLASSIFICATION 

Sec. 4.5-51. - Classification plan. 
(a)  The following constitute the positions to be included within the classification plan of the civil service system. 
(1)  Finance director; 
(2)  Foreman of public works; 
(3)  Head librarian; 
(4)  Superintendent-Waste water control. 
(b)  The duties, responsibilities and minimum qualifications of the aforesaid civil service positions shall be as set forth in this section. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 4.1, 4.2; Ord. of 11-19-02(2)) 
Secs. 4.5-52-4.5-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMPENSATION 

Sec. 4.5-61. - Salary schedule to be established. 
    For each classified position, the town shall establish a schedule which shall contain a minimum salary and a maximum salary. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.1) 
Sec. 4.5-62. - Consideration for pay increases. 
    At the recommendation of the first selectman with the approval of the majority of the board of selectmen, employees in civil service will be considered for pay increases, once per year. The board of selectmen will make these recommendations to the board of finance by February 15 to be effective July 1 of the same year. In the case of the head librarian, any such recommendations shall be made by the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.2) 
Sec. 4.5-63. - Satisfactory service required for salary increase. 
    Increase in salary for individual employees shall be primarily based upon satisfactory service. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.3) 
Sec. 4.5-64. - Minimum rate of pay. 
    The minimum rate of pay for a particular position shall normally be offered for recruitment purposes. The first selectman may with the approval of the board of selectmen, offer a rate of pay above the minimum provided, however, that the qualifications of the applicant are superior to those of competing applicants, and/or employees cannot be secured at the minimum rate due to a shortage of qualified applicants available at the minimum rate. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.4) 
Sec. 4.5-65. - Compensation upon reassignment. 
    If a town employee is temporarily reassigned to a position of higher level pay, compensation will be based upon the higher salary for the duration of the reassignment. Reassignment must be for a period of at least 30 days to receive a higher salary. If reassigned at a lower level of pay, compensation will be based upon employee's present salary. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.5) 
Sec. 4.5-66. - Compensation for probational employees. 
    The compensation for probational employees will be set forth for each position in the compensation schedule established in section 4.5-61. Such compensation will not be adjusted except with the majority approval of the board of selectmen. Probationary employees will not receive entry level salary until the probationary period has been completed. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.6) 
Sec. 4.5-67. - Vacation leave. 
    Permanent full time employees under civil service will be entitled to the following vacation time: two weeks after 12 months employment, three weeks after five years employment. One extra day for each additional year of employment after ten years with a maximum of four weeks after 15 years of continuous employment. After 20 years of continuous employment the maximum vacation will be five weeks. Any vacation leave shall be taken within the fiscal year in which it was earned. Any existing contract dealing with affected employees will be honored. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.7) 
Sec. 4.5-68. - Paid holidays. 
    The following holidays shall be observed by all permanent full time employees and shall be granted with pay: 
New Years Day 
Martin Luther King Day 
Presidents' Day 
Good Friday 
Memorial Day 
Independence Day 
Labor Day 
Columbus Day 
Veteran's Day 
Election Day 
Thanksgiving Day 
Day after Thanksgiving 
Christmas Eve Day 
Christmas 
The half day on December 31. 
    When a holiday falls on a Saturday, the day before the holiday will be observed. When the holiday fails on a Sunday, the day after the holiday will be observed. There will however, be no compensation day given if Christmas Eve Day or December 31 falls on a Saturday or Sunday. In the case of the head librarian, at the discretion of the library board of directors, the library may remain open on the following holidays: Martin Luther King Day, Presidents' Day, Columbus Day, Election Day and the day after Thanksgiving. If the library is opened on such days the head librarian shall be entitled to such "floating holiday" in compensation. Said floating holiday shall be taken within two weeks of the holiday upon which the library remains open. In the case of the foreman of the department of public works, such employee shall be entitled to the same holidays as granted under the contract provided for the union members of the department of public works. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.8) 
Sec. 4.5-69. - Sick leave. 
    All permanent full time employees shall be granted sick leave with pay at the rate of one and one-quarter (11/4) days per month. 15 sick days per year are the maximum allowed. After five consecutive sick days are used under this section, a doctor's slip must be presented before an employee may be permitted to return to work. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.9) 
Sec. 4.5-70. - Accumulation of unused sick leave. 
(a)  No unused sick leave of any employee may be accumulated after April 1, 1985. Employees may retain the unused sick leave accumulated prior to April 1, 1985 but no further accumulations earned after that date will be permitted, Unused sick leave accumulated prior to April 1, 1985 may be used in one of the following ways: 
(1)  The employee may use sick accumulation as sick leave. 
(2)  The employee may use such accumulation until termination of his employment, as vacation time subject to the approval of the board of selectmen or of the library board of directors subject to departmental needs. 
(3)  The employee may elect to retain such accumulation until termination of his employment, at which time the employee shall be paid at 50 percent of his prevailing day rate as of January 1, 1994, times the number of days accumulated. 
(b)  As of April 1, 1985 in the final pay period of each fiscal year, each employee shall be paid 66 2/3 percent the value of each sick day remaining unused for that year. Should an employee be paid for a day subsequently used, the day shall be deducted from the employee's next pay check. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.10) 
Sec. 4.5-71. - Leave of absence without pay. 
    The first selectman with the majority vote of the board of selectmen (or the library board of directors in the case of the head librarian) may grant leave of absence without pay to any employee, upon the employee's request. Such leave shall be for a period not to exceed three months. This leave of absence must be due to illness or personal problems. No employee will be granted a leave of absence to work at another job. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.11) 
Sec. 4.5-72. - Paid personal leave. 
    Each full time employee will be allowed three personal days off each year. If these are not used, no compensation will be given. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.12) 
Sec. 4.5-73. - Group insurance. 
    Group insurance will be granted to all civil service employees and retirees who retire after the age 591/2 at the town's expense in accordance with the town's group insurance plan, or such plan as the town may adopt in the future. Such insurance benefits may be offered to said employee's families at the employee's expense. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.13) 
Sec. 4.5-74. - Retirement benefits. 
    Retirement benefits will be granted in accordance with the municipal retirement plan. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.14) 
Sec. 4.5-75. - Funeral leave. 
    All full time civil service employees will be allowed funeral leave as follows: 
(1)  Three days for spouses, children, parents, parents-in-law, brother and sister. 
(2)  One day for other relatives who shall include uncle, aunt, cousin, brother-in-law, sister-in-law. 
    Permission to attend the funeral service of a close acquaintance without compensation may be obtained from the first selectman or in the case of the head librarian, from the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.15) 
Sec. 4.5-76. - Leave for jury duty. 
    Employees shall be granted leaves of absence for required jury duty. Such employees shall receive the portion of their regular salary which will together with their pay for jury duty or fees equal their total salary for the same period. Pay vouchers shall be submitted to ascertain the pay due to the employee. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.16) 
Sec. 4.5-77. - Military training duty leave. 
    Military training duty leave shall be granted to regular employees when they are required to serve on active reserve or on National Guard duty. Such employees shall receive that portion of their regular salary which will with their pay for military service equal their total salary for the same period. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.17) 
Sec. 4.5-78. - Compensation for use of private automobile for official town business. 
    An employee authorized by the immediate supervisor to use his private automobile for official town business shall be compensated at a rate established by the board of selectmen. Claims must be submitted weekly to the supervisor. Vehicles must be properly insured indemnifying the town against liability. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.18) 
Sec. 4.5-79. - Accumulated vacation leave and extra hours worked. 
    Upon adoption of this ordinance all accumulated vacations and extra hours worked which have been approved by the department head will be honored. All new vacation days and extra time must adhere to the above provisions. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 5.19) 
Secs. 4.5-80-4.5-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RECRUITMENT 

Sec. 4.5-91. - Announcement of vacancies. 
(a)  The first selectman (or the library board of directors with regard to the position of head librarian) shall make known all permanent vacancies for all positions in civil service to the civil service commission within ten days of notification of vacancies. The civil service commission will post announcements for such vacancies in at least one newspaper having general circulation in the area, and in such other places they deem necessary at the time such permanent vacancies are given to said commission in writing from the first selectman (or the library board of directors). All persons on the eligibility list or employees who wish to transfer will be considered. 
(b)  Any announcement for vacancies shall include the following: 
(1)  Job title; 
(2)  Salary ranges; 
(3)  Nature of work; 
(4)  Minimum qualifications; 
(5)  Closing date for application and 
(6)  Any additional information regarding the position deemed necessary by the civil service commission. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 6.0, 6.1) 
Sec. 4.5-92. - Application for employment. 
    Application shall be made on forms provided by the first selectman (library board of directors). All applications will be available at the first selectman's office (or the library board of directors) and when completed will be returned there. When all applications have been returned and the closing date has passed the first selectman (or the library board of directors) will turn the applications over to the civil service commission for review. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 6.2) 
Sec. 4.5-93. - Security of personal information. 
    As part of the application procedure, references provided by the applicants shall be reviewed by the civil service commission. All such information is to be treated as privileged information. All such personal information will be secured in locked files and/or compartments in the first selectman's office. The board of selectmen and/or the library board of directors will determine who has access to the files. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 6.3) 
Sec. 4.5-94. - Grounds for rejection of application. 
    The civil service commission shall be authorized to reject any application for the following reasons: 
(1)  Lack of education, experience, and/or qualifications. 
(2)  Conviction of a felony, infamous crime, or crime involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  Falsifying any part of the application. 
(4)  Use of political pressure or bribery to secure the position. 
(5)  Direct or indirect knowledge of the contents of any part of the examination to which the applicant was not entitled. 
(6)  Involvement in the completion, administration or correction of the examination. 
(7)  Failure to submit completed examination within the allotted time. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 6.4) 
Sec. 4.5-95. - Notification of rejections. 
    Whenever an application is rejected, the civil service commission shall notify the applicant, in writing, certified mail, return receipt requested of such rejection. The letter shall include a notice informing the applicant of his right to review pursuant to section 4.5-96 hereof. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 6.5) 
Sec. 4.5-96. - Right of review. 
    Any applicant whose application has been rejected may request in writing a review of said application. Such request shall be made prior to any examination for the position in question. The decision of the civil service commission shall be final. The civil service commission shall have the power to allow the applicant to take part in the examination pending their review of the appeal. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 6.6) 
Sec. 4.5-97. - Policy of non-discrimination. 
    No person applying for a position with the Town of Seymour shall be discriminated against because of race, religion, sex, age, national origin or political affiliation. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 6.7) 
Secs. 4.5-98-4.5-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - EXAMINATIONS 

Sec. 4.5-111. - Examination may be required. 
    All appointments to positions within the civil service of the Town of Seymour shall be made as provided herein. The examination and testing for each position shall be set forth in each job description where examinations are required. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.0) 
Sec. 4.5-112. - Examination process. 
    The impartial examination process shall be of a practical nature and shall relate to subjects which in the opinion of the civil service commission fairly measure the relative capabilities of persons examined to execute the duties and responsibilities of the position sought. For positions involving semi-skilled or unskilled labor or custodial work, the civil service system may adopt or authorize use of other procedures as they determine may be appropriate, while assuring a selection of such employees on the basis of merit and fitness, unless otherwise provided by the job description. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.1) 
Sec. 4.5-113. - Types of examination. 
    Except as otherwise provided by ordinance, the type of examination shall be determined by the civil service commission and may include, but shall not be limited to, written, oral, physical, mental and/or performance or any combination thereof. The department head shall be consulted as to the type of examination given in each instance. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.2) 
Sec. 4.5-114. - Examinations to be openly competitive. 
    All examinations shall be of an open competitive nature and all applicants meeting the prescribed requirements shall be allowed to participate, except as noted in section 4.5-117 of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.3) 
Sec. 4.5-115. - Use of outside testing agencies. 
    The civil service commission shall be allowed to contract with any competent agency or individual for the purpose of preparing and for administering such examinations. In the absence of such contract, the civil service commission or a portion thereof, shall perform said duties or may delegate their performance. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.4) 
Sec. 4.5-116. - Notification of applicants. 
    All qualified applicants shall be notified, in writing of the time, place and date of the examination by the civil service commission. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.5) 
Sec. 4.5-117. - Applicant required to pass each part of examination. 
    In any examination process which requires more than one test, the applicant shall be required to achieve the passing grade for each test in order to continue the examination process. If the applicant fails to achieve the passing grade in any part of the examination process then he will not be allowed to continue and shall be notified in writing by the civil service commission. If the applicant in such an examination achieves a passing grade in any part of the examination process, than he shall be allowed to continue and shall be notified in writing by the civil service commission of his grade and the date of the next part of the examination process. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.6) 
Sec. 4.5-118. - Promotional examinations. 
    Promotional examinations within the civil service system shall be of a competitive nature and shall in general be as provided in sections 4.5-112 and 4.5-113 with due allowance for difference due to the promotional nature of the examination. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.7) 
Sec. 4.5-119. - Right of employees to apply for examinations. 
    No department head or administrator shall deny any employee permission to apply for any examination. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.8) 
Sec. 4.5-120. - Notification of final grade. 
    Each applicant who has completed all phases of the examination procedure shall be notified in writing by the civil service commission of his final grade rank. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.9) 
Sec. 4.5-121. - Right to inspect examination papers. 
    Each applicant shall be entitled to inspect his examination papers and/or grading papers, under conditions prescribed by the civil service commission. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.10) 
Sec. 4.5-122. - Passing grade to be announced in advance. 
    The passing grade for each examination or part thereof shall be determined and announced in advance by the civil service commission. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 7.11) 
Secs. 4.5-123-4.5-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - APPOINTMENTS 

Sec. 4.5-131. - Eligibility list prepared. 
    The civil service commission shall prepare an eligibility list of all applicants who have successfully completed the testing procedure. Said eligibility list shall include the applicant's name, final grade and rank. This list shall remain in effect for a period of one year and may be extended by the civil service commission for an additional one year. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.0) 
Sec. 4.5-132. - Annual update of eligibility list. 
    The civil service commission or its designee shall on/or before the anniversary date of the eligibility list, contact those persons whose names appear on said list to inquire whether or not they wish to have their names remain on said list. Those applicants who desire their names to be removed shall notify the civil service commission in writing and said notice shall be attached to the eligibility list. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.1) 
Sec. 4.5-133. - Use of eligibility list in filling vacancy. 
    When a vacancy is to be filled, the civil service commission shall certify to the appointing authority the names of the top three persons from the eligibility list. A recommendation to the appointing authority shall also be made from the applicable department head. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.2) 
Sec. 4.5-134. - Appointing authority to approve eligible applicant. 
    The appointing authority, i.e., the board of selectmen or library board of directors, shall select an applicant from said certified list. Said selection shall be by majority vote of the board of selectmen or library board of directors where a quorum is present. The applicant chosen shall be notified in writing by certified mail of such appointment and shall accept said appointment within seven days. One representative of the civil service commission and the appropriate department head shall have the right to be present when the appointing authority considers the appointment. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.3) 
Sec. 4.5-135. - Failure of applicant to accept position. 
    If the applicant fails to accept within the allowed time period, then the appointing authority shall select another applicant from the certified list. This procedure shall be continued until a successful candidate accepts the position or until the certified list is exhausted. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.4) 
Sec. 4.5-136. - Provisional appointment without examination. 
    Provisional appointments without examination may be made only when there is no certified list, for no more than six months and except as provided in section 4.5-137, only of persons qualified. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.5) 
Sec. 4.5-137. - Emergency appointment. 
    In the event of an emergency, the appointing authority may appoint any individual to a position to prevent the stoppage of public business and/or loss or serious inconvenience to the public for a period not greater that 60 days. Such appointment shall be valid only for the duration of said emergency but in any event not longer than 60 days. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 8.6) 
Secs. 4.5-138-4.5-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PROBATION 

Sec. 4.5-151. - Probationary period required for new employees. 
    All new employees shall be required to serve a probationary period of six months. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 9.0) 
Sec. 4.5-152. - Performance reports. 
    During the probationary period of any new employee, the supervisor in charge of the department shall submit to the appointing authority a written performance report at the end of 30 days, 90 days and three weeks prior to the end of the employee's probationary period. Such reports and their approval by the appointing authority are definite requisites for permanent appointment and the privileges that accompany it. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 9.1) 
Sec. 4.5-153. - Termination after thirty working days. 
    An employee may be terminated at any time after 30 working days of probationary period by the appointing authority on the written recommendation of the department head that the employee failed to meet the minimum standards for the performance of the job. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 9.2) 
Sec. 4.5-154. - Notice of unsatisfactory performance or deficiencies. 
    Within two months from the beginning of a probationary period, the department head shall, in writing, notice the employee if he (she) is not performing satisfactorily. The notice shall detail the areas of the job in which the department head feels the employee is not performing to standard. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 9.3) 
Sec. 4.5-155. - No appeal of termination during probationary period. 
    There shall be no appeal of the decision to terminate a probationary employee. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 9.4) 
Sec. 4.5-156. - Successful completion of probationary period. 
    Upon successful completion of the stated probationary period, the first selectman shall notify the employee of his permanent status with the Town of Seymour. In the case of the head librarian, the library board of directors shall make such notification. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 9.5) 
Secs. 4.5-157-4.5-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CONDUCT OF EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 4.5-171. - Annual evaluation of employees. 
    All employees shall be evaluated annually by their respective department heads, in writing on forms supplied by the first selectman or in the case of the head librarian, by the library board of directors. A copy of said evaluation shall be signed by both the employee and the department head and forwarded to the first selectman or in the case of the head librarian by the employee and a representative of the library board of directors and forwarded to the library board of directors. After such review by said officials, the evaluations shall be placed in the employee's file. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.0) 
Sec. 4.5-172. - Evaluation of department heads and head librarian. 
    Evaluations of department heads will be made by the first selectman. Evaluations of the head librarian will be made by the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.1) 
Sec. 4.5-173. - Review of evaluations. 
    All evaluations will be reviewed by the board of selectmen or in the case of the head librarian, by the library board of directors, before being placed in the employee's file. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.2) 
Sec. 4.5-174. - Length of basic work week. 
    The basic work week shall consist of 35 hours unless provided otherwise by the board of selectmen or in the case of the head librarian by the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.3) 
Sec. 4.5-175. - Responsibility of department heads. 
(a)  Department heads will be responsible for all employees in their departments. Any problems concerning an employee will be reported by the department head to the first selectmen who will report same to the board of selectmen where appropriate action will be taken. In the case of the head librarian, any problems concerning same will be reported to the library board of directors where appropriate action will be taken. 
(b)  Department heads will conduct their departments in a professional manner. All problems with department heads will be addressed and action taken by the board of selectmen or in the case of the head librarian by the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 10.4, 10.5) 
Sec. 4.5-176. - Jurisdiction over employees. 
    All employees employed in civil service will come under the jurisdiction of the first selectman and the board of selectmen with the exception of the head librarian who will come under the jurisdiction of the library board of directors. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.6) 
Sec. 4.5-177. - Employees to follow rules and regulations. 
    All civil service employees shall follow all the rules and regulations for civil service and the civil service ordinance. Regulations governing civil service may be amended by the majority vote of the board of selectmen. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.7) 
Sec. 4.5-178. - Political activity by employees. 
    Political activity concerning members of the civil service shall be in accordance with section 11.2 of the Charter. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 10.8) 
Secs. 4.5-179-4.5-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - RETIREMENT 

Sec. 4.5-191. - Retirement policy. 
    All employees of the civil service system shall be subject to the rules as to retirement as established by the town's retirement policy and/or ordinance as same may be amended from time to time by said town. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 11.1) 
Sec. 4.5-192. - Participation in Connecticut Municipal Retirement System. 
    Said employees shall also be subject to the town's participation in the Connecticut Municipal Retirement System. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 11.2) 
Secs. 4.5-193-4.5-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - DISCIPLINARY PROCEDURES 

Sec. 4.5-201. - Reasons for disciplinary action. 
    Disciplinary action against any employee shall be taken only for one or more (but not limited to) the following reasons: 
(1)  Dishonesty -defined as including falsification of records, financial dishonesty, fraud, theft and willful misrepresentation; 
(2)  Insubordination -defined as refusal to carry out orders of the department head, or first selectman or of any person delegated authority over the employee; 
(3)  Action detrimental to the town -defined as the use of alcohol, drugs or excess of temperament which impede the conduct of daily business; 
(4)  Violence, threats of violence or insults -defined as assaults upon fellow workers, or on any person who is transacting business, verbal abuse which includes but is not limited to abusive language directed at any of the foregoing or participation in any action which endanger the bodily safety of any of the foregoing; 
(5)  Criminal conduct -defined as a conviction of a misdemeanor involving the theft of property or misappropriation of funds or of any felony committed while in the employ of the Town, or theft or destruction of town property; 
(6)  Deficiency in performance of work -defined as inefficiency, habitual tardiness, or absenteeism, the performance of unauthorized services for others during work hours; the refusal or failure to perform a designated quantity and quality of work; or fraudulently obtaining sick or injury leave. 
(7)  Unauthorized political activity -defined as engaging in political activity prohibited by section 11.2 of the town Charter; and 
(8)  Any other conduct materially impairing the efficiently with which the town government provides services to the citizens of the community. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 12.1) 
Sec. 4.5-202. - Classes of disciplinary action. 
    There shall be three classes of disciplinary action. These classes progress from Class I to Class III, depending on the repetition and/or severity of the offense. Class I disciplinary action can be taken at the discretion of the individual department head. Any action taken in Class II may be taken with the approval of the first selectman. Class III disciplinary action may only be taken with the approval of the majority of the board of selectmen. With regard to the head librarian, all disciplinary action may only be taken with the approval of the majority of the library board of directors and the references to the department head and first selectman shall be intended to refer to the library board of directors concerning the head librarian. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 12.2) 
Sec. 4.5-203. - Disciplinary action-Class I. 
    Class I disciplinary action consists of a written reprimand. After oral discussions with the employee and the department head, a copy of said reprimand is sent to the first selectman to be placed in the employee's permanent file. The employee, upon receipt of said reprimand, may request a hearing with the first selectman to discuss the nature of the disciplinary action. The first selectman, may, upon hearing the employee's and department head statements, decide whether or not to place the written reprimand in the employee's permanent file. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 12.3) 
Sec. 4.5-204. - Same-Class II. 
(a)  A Class II disciplinary action shall consist of suspension without pay. This may be imposed after a series of repeated offenses or after a serious offense. The employee must be notified at least three days before the effective date of any such action. This letter of notification must clearly state the nature of the offense, the length of the suspension and the fact that the employee may appeal the ordered absence without pay. A maximum penalty under Class II action shall be a suspension to a maximum of five working days. 
(b)  Within the three-day notification period, the individual may request an appointment with the first selectman who on the basis of the employee's and department head's statements and/or results of an investigation may determine whether of not the suspension will remain in effect. The letter of notification to the employee must bear the signatures of both the department head and the first selectman. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 12.4, 12.5) 
Sec. 4.5-205. - Same-Class III. 
(a)  There are two sections to a Class III disciplinary action and they are as follows: 
(1)  Demotion: The transfer of an employee to a lower grade and 
(2)  Dismissal: The complete separation of an employee from employment with the town. 
(b)  The procedure for both sections of Class III are the same. Any action taken in this class must be approved by the board of selectmen except in the case of the head librarian which shall require the approval of a majority of the board of library directors. The signature of the first selectman and the department head or the president of the library board of directors must appear on the letter of notification which is sent to the individual and the civil service commission by certified mail. 
(c)  The letter of notification must clearly state the nature of the offense, advise the employee of his right to appeal to the civil service commission and state that the appeal must be taken within 14 days of the effective date of action. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 12.6, 12.7) 
Secs. 4.5-206-4.5-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - SEPARATIONS 

Sec. 4.5-211. - Separations generally. 
(a)  The tenure of every employee shall be conditioned upon behavior, satisfactory performance of duties, satisfactory attendance and continued capability for the job position. 
(b)  Resignation, layoff, dismissal, disability, death and retirement are considered separations. All separations shall be accomplished in the manner indicated. At the time of separation and prior to final payment to the employee, all records, assets or other items of town property in the employee's custody shall be transferred to the department head or in the case of a department head to the first selectman. In the case of the head librarian such transfer shall be made to the library board of directors. Any amount due because of shortage in the above accounting shall be withheld from the employee's final compensation or collected through other appropriate action. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, §§ 13.0, 13.1) 
Sec. 4.5-212. - Payment for earned salary and vacation leave. 
    Employees who leave the town service in good standing shall receive payment for all earned salary and vacation leave subject to deductions made pursuant to section 13.1(b). Effective April 1, 1985 such payments shall include sick leave earned. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 13.2) 
Sec. 4.5-213. - Reasons for separation. 
    Employees may be separated from employment with the town for the following reasons: 
(1)  Disciplinary termination: As set forth in Article XII. 
(2)  Medical termination: Upon certification by a physician that the individual is not physically or, in the alternative, mentally capable of carrying out the duties of his position. If there is a disagreement between the employee and the town as to the existence of such disability, the employee shall have the right of appeal to the civil service commission. 
(3)  Resignation: Any employee in good standing desiring to leave the position shall submit a written resignation stating the effective date. Such notice should be at lest 14 days prior to the desired date of termination. The department head may permit a shorter period of notice because of unusual circumstances. The resignation shall be forwarded to the first selectman with a statement by the department head as to the resigned employee's service performance. In case of the head librarian such notice shall be forwarded to the library board of directors. A copy of such notice shall be placed in the personnel file of the employee. 
(4)  Reduction of force: 
a.  When a position must be discontinued or abolished because of lack of work or lack of funds, the department head and/or the first selectman may recommend that such action of discontinuance be taken. The first selectman with the concurrence of a majority of the board of selectmen may discontinue such positions because of lack of work or funds. In the case of the head librarian, the library board of directors may take such action by a majority vote of the board. 
b.  The first selectman by virtue of a majority vote of the board of selectmen shall determine the order of layoff of employees on basis of the relative suitability for the jobs that remain and the length of continuous service with the town. If it is found that two or more persons in a department in which a layoff is to be made have equal ratings, the order of layoff in such cases shall be in the inverse order of the date of initial employment. In the case of the head librarian, the library board of directors shall have the power to determine the order of layoff. 
c.  In normal circumstances permanent employees subject to layoff shall be notified in writing two calendar weeks prior to the effective date. 
d.  Any laid-off employee shall have the right to be recalled if the position again becomes open. Notice of recall shall be given in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested and must be accepted in writing [within] ten days of receipt. If the employee elects not to return to work, his employment with the town shall be automatically terminated. 
(5)  Failure to meet performance standards during first 30 days of probationary period: At any time subsequent to the first 30 days during the probationary period, the first selectman, upon the recommendation of the department head may separate an employee whose performance does not meet required standards with the concurrence of a majority vote of the board of selectmen. In the case of the head librarian, such action may be taken with the concurrence of a majority vote of the library board of directors. 
(6)  Death: Separation shall be effective as of the date of death. All compensation due shall be paid to the estate of the employee, except for such sums as by law may be due to the surviving spouse. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 13.3) 
Secs. 4.5-214-4.5-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - RECORDS 

Sec. 4.5-221. - First selectman. 
    The first selectman shall maintain adequate records of the proceedings of the board of selectman and of his own official acts. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 14.1) 
Sec. 4.5-222. - Civil service commission. 
    The civil service commission shall maintain an adequate record of the examination record of every candidate and the employment record of every employee. Said records shall be kept and maintained in the first selectman's office. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 14.2) 
Secs. 4.5-223-4.5-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - CIVIL SERVICE POSITION DESCRIPTIONS 

Sec. 4.5-231. - Positions to be included in the civil service. 
    The following are the job descriptions of the positions to be included in the civil service system of the town: 
(1)  Finance director: 
a.  Any employee in this class is responsible for the receipt, custody, investment and disbursement of all town funds; the administration of municipal debts; the maintenance of accounting records; and the preparation of financial reports covering all town activities and all funds. 
b.  Work is performed under the general direction of the first selectman and is subject to the administrative review through discussions, reports and observation and to an annual financial audit. Supervision is exercised over account clerk and clerical employees. 
(2)  Foreman of public works: Supervises work in the construction, maintenance and repair or operation of the town's public works facilities and services. Is responsible for planning, organizing and supervising the daily work of subordinate supervisory, skilled and unskilled workers and equipment operations engaged in road maintenance, grounds maintenance, equipment maintenance and related activities. Supervises transfer station. Works under general supervision of first selectman. 
(3)  Head librarian: The library administrator, responsible for all library functions. Independent judgement and authority are exercised in making decisions related to overseeing the annual budget, directing the staff, caring for the library's equipment and collection and producing a comprehensive program of library service to the community. Directly responsible to the board of library directors. Responsible for work of all library staff and volunteers. 
(4)  Superintendent of waste water control: Exercises supervision of the Seymour Water Pollution Control Plant. The superintendent is responsible for the supervision of other employees at the waste water control plant. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 15.1; Ord. of 11-19-02(2)) 
Sec. 4.5-232. - Cost of educational requirements. 
    Any cost of any educational requirements necessary to qualify for the positions covered by this ordinance will be paid for by the Town of Seymour. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 15.2) 
Sec. 4.5-233. - Copies of civil service ordinance and personnel rules to be available. 
    Copies of this ordinance and personnel rules and amendments thereto will be available at Town Hall and all members of the civil service system will be provided with a copy of same. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 15.3) 
Secs. 4.5-234-4.5-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - LEGALITY 

Sec. 4.5-241. - Severability. 
    Should any part of this ordinance be declared illegal, the board of selectmen declares that is would have adopted all the other provisions notwithstanding such illegality of a part and all remaining parts shall remain in effect. 
(Ord. of 9-6-94, § 16.1)

Sec. 5-5. - Board for admission of electors-Composition. 
    The board for admission of electors in the town shall consist of the town clerk and the registrars of voters to act under the provisions of section 9-15a of the general statutes.

Sec. 5-6. - Same-Sessions. 
    The board for admission of electors is authorized to hold sessions to examine the qualifications of electors and admit to the elector's oath those found qualified on such day of the third full week beginning with Sunday of each of the months of June and July of the odd-numbered years as the board for admission of electors may designate. 
(Code 1961, § 7-3) 
Sec. 5-7. - Registrars of voters; term of office. 
(a)  The registrars of voters for the town shall be elected for a term of four years commencing with the election on November 7, 1978. 
(b)  Such term of office shall begin on the Wednesday following the first Monday of January succeeding their election. 
(Ord. of 10-17-78)
