Sec. 10-1. - Junkyard locations. 
    No further applications for motor junkyard permits shall be granted for any proposed site within the limits of the town except for such sites or locations where duly licensed motor vehicle junkyards are already in operation. 
(Code 1961, § 12-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Hawkers, peddlers, vendors, canvassers and solicitors. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  A "hawker" is defined as an itinerant or traveling trader, who carries goods about, in order to sell them, and who actually sells them to purchasers at that time, by offering for sale on the streets by outcry or by attracting the attention of persons by exposing goods in a public place, or by placards, labels or signals. 
(2)  A "peddler" or "vendor" is defined as any person, whether principal or agent, who shall travel from place to place or from house to house, taking or attempting to take orders for sales of goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future, or for services to be performed at any time without previous arrangement with such person so requesting such services, whether or not such individual shall carry or expose for sale a sample of the subject of such sale, or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
(3)  A "canvasser" is defined as any person who shall travel from place to place or from house to house eliciting survey or census information, or seeking to distribute materials for whatever purpose. 
(4)  A "solicitor" is defined as any person who shall travel from place to place or from house to house soliciting donations of either money, personal goods, or services for whatever purposes. 
(b)  License required: No person except those exempted by the statutes of the state shall engage in hawking, peddling, vending, canvassing or soliciting activities as defined in subsection (a) within the town, without having obtained from the chief of police a license therefor as required by this section. No person shall sell or offer for sale upon a public street, sidewalk or other public place any article whose purpose, whether intended or by common usage, is to be immediately consumed or used in such a way as to cause littering. Such articles which are hereby prohibited shall include, but are not necessarily limited to, spray string, stink bombs and such other similar articles which cause immediate littering to public places. 
(c)  License issuance; classes: Nontransferable licenses obtained January 1, 1989 shall expire December 31st of the calendar year in which they were issued. Licenses shall be in two classes: 
(1)  Class A for nonprofit activities; 
(2)  Class B for all others. 
All licenses in effect at the time of adoption of this section shall expire January first. 
(d)  Class A licenses: Class A licenses shall be issued to any legally declared nonprofit organization existing within the Town of Seymour or a certified representative of such an organization. 
(e)  Class B licenses: Class B licenses shall be issued to all other individuals or organizations. 
(f)  License processing period: A class B license shall not be issued prior to 21 days from the date of application and must be signed by the chief of police and the first selectman. A class A license may be issued prior to the 21-day processing period upon the recommendation of the chief of police and approval by the first selectman. 
(g)  License applications: Any person making an application for either a class A or a class B license shall furnish in writing, on a form to be furnished by the chief of police, the following information: 
(1)  Name and personal physical description of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address or place of housing of the applicant; 
(3)  A detailed description of the nature of the services or goods to be sold, if any, including the name of the manufacture, publisher, distributor or parent company where applicable; 
(4)  The applicant shall furnish the name and address of the organization for whom he is undertaking any of the activities listed in subsection (a) of this section; 
(5)  The length of time for which the applicant wishes to engage in any of the activities listed in subsection (a) of this section; 
(6)  The place where goods or services are to be sold or distributed from; 
(7)  The make, model, color and registration number of the vehicles, if any, to be used by the applicant, whether or not it be owned by the applicant; 
(8)  The chief of police at his discretion, may require the applicant to submit fingerprints as may be necessary to complete a background investigation of the applicant's moral character; 
(9)  At the discretion of the chief of police, the applicant shall submit a photograph of himself, which will remain with the application for a period not to exceed five years. 
(h)  License fee generally: There shall be no fee for a class A license. The fee for a class B license shall be $200.00 for each individual obtaining such a license, or a fee of $500.00 for each vehicle used, not to exceed five persons. For holidays and special events as defined by the board of selectmen, the board of selectmen, at its discretion, may establish a special fee schedule for vendors. 
A license fee shall not be collected from any resident of the state who has resided within the state for a period of two years and who is a veteran who served in time of war as defined by section 27-103 of the general statutes. Any veteran applying for the fee exemption shall produce his military discharge papers for inspection, together with a certificate that the applicant is a resident of the state, upon demand by the chief of police. The issuance of a license shall not be deferred for more than seven days for such veteran. 
A resident taxpayer or a business located within the town or a charitable organization located within the town may apply to the board of selectmen for a waiver of the class B license fee. The board of selectmen may, at its discretion, grant such a waiver. 
(i)  Investigation of applicant; issuance of license: Upon receipt of an application by the chief of police, a reasonable investigation may be conducted by the police department under the direction of the chief of police, to confirm that the applicant is of good moral character and proposes to engage in a lawful activity. Said investigation shall be conducted within 21 days of the receipt of an application. After review and approval of the application by the chief of police and the first selectman, the chief of police shall issue an original permit to the applicant provided more than 21 days have expired since the filing of the application, except as otherwise provided in subsection (f) of this section, and provided that the applicant pays the fee as set forth in subsection (h) of this section. 
Each permit issued shall bear the original raised seal of the town clerk and any unauthorized use of said permit by anyone shall result in a fine of $100.00 for each offense. The applicants for vendors' licenses shall provide such insurance coverage as the town may require. 
(j)  License fee to be paid before issuance: No license shall be issued until the applicant shall have paid the required fee to the town clerk at the office of the town clerk. 
(k)  License to be carried by licensee; display of license: After the license has been issued by the chief of police, the license shall be carried by the licensee at all times while conducting activities listed in subsection (a). The license shall be exhibited by the licensee whenever he is requested to do so by any police officer or by any person so solicited. 
(l)  Suspension, revocation of license: Any such license issued by chief of police may be suspended by the chief of police for violation of any state or federal law, or whenever the holder of such permit shall in the judgement of the chief of police cease to possess the character qualifications required by this section for the issuance of such permit. If any license is suspended or revoked the holder of such license may within five days of notice of the suspension or revocation, file an appeal of the decision of the chief of police to the board of police commissioners. The board of police commissioners shall have the authority to sustain, amend or rescind the suspension or revocation. 
(m)  Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $199.00 for each offense. 
(n)  Reserved. 
(o)  Special permit: Legally declared nonprofit organizations which host or sponsor an event which will be held at a single location and during which profit-making parties will be allowed to engage in any activities listed in subsection (a) of this section, must obtain a license as herein provided. The host or sponsor shall apply for a class A license which shall apply to and cover all nonprofit organizations participating in the event. The host or sponsor organization shall additionally collect a special $1.00 fee from each participating profit-making party in lieu of the individual class B fees required by subsection (h) of this section and return the collected fees to the town clerk. The host or sponsor shall also assume responsibility for all liabilities related to the event and shall ensure that the location of the event is left in the same condition as existed prior to the event. The collection of the special $1.00 fee shall become effective on January 1, 1977. 
(p)  Reserved. 
(q)  Any person granted a license under this section may not operate within 1,000 feet of an existing business of a like nature located within the town. 
(Code 1961, § 12-2; Ord. of 4-30-85; Ord. of 8-16-88, §§ (1)-(5); Ord. of 3-3-92; Ord. of 12-6-94(1); Ord. if 7-18-95; Ord. of 6-29-98) 
State Law reference- Hawkers and peddlers, G.S. § 21-36 et seq.; ordinances authorized, G.S. § 21-37. 
Sec. 10-3. - Trailers and trailer parks. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  "Multiple dwelling" means any trailer designed and intended to accommodate more than one family. 
(2)  "Park" means trailer coach park. 
(3)  "Trailer coach" means any portable structure or vehicle so constructed and designed as to permit occupancy thereof for dwelling or sleeping purposes for one family. 
(4)  "Trailer coach park" means any plot of ground upon which two or more trailer coaches, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodation. 
(5)  "Trailer coach space" means a plot of ground available to an owner for use as a site for a trailer coach. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
(b)  Parks prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the limits of the town, any multiple dwelling, any park, or any trailer coach park, within the contemplation of this section. 
(c)  License for coaches required; fee. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate any trailer coach unless such person shall first obtain a license therefor. The license fee for each trailer coach shall be $25.00. 
(d)  Applications for coach licenses. Application for a trailer coach license shall be filed with and issued by the board of selectmen. Applications shall be in writing signed by the applicant, accompanied by the license fee and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The location and legal description of the trailer coach; 
(3)  The description of the trailer coach space to be used exclusively for the site of said trailer coach. The lot site for the trailer shall be not less than 5,000 square feet where it is served by a public sewer system and a public water supply, and not less than 25,000 square feet on a lot not less than 100 feet wide where it is not served by a public sewer system and a public water supply; 
(4)  That the applicant has title to the trailer coach and also to the trailer coach space to be used as a site; 
(5)  That the applicant will conform to all municipal and state ordinances and laws existing pertaining to health, sanitation, nuisance and fire. 
(e)  Revocation; reissuance of coach licenses. The board of selectmen may revoke any license to maintain and operate any trailer coach when the licensee has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provision of this section. After such conviction, the license may be reissued if the circumstances leading to the conviction have been remedied. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined no more than $25.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1961, § 12-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Blasting. 
(a)  Pre-blast inspections. 
(1)  Whenever blasting operations are to be conducted within 200 feet of a structure which is neither owned nor leased by the project contractor or the blaster, the following precautions shall be adhered to: 
a.  A pre-blast inspection of all structures within 200 feet range shall be conducted; 
b.  The inspection shall include both interior and exterior visible and accessible areas; 
c.  The inspection record shall be available for inspection by the owner of the structure. A copy of said report shall be forwarded to the fire marshal's office at least three working days prior to blasting operations. 
(2)  The requirements of this section shall be considered satisfied under the following conditions: 
a.  If three unsuccessful attempts have been made to notify the owner/occupant of the structure; 
b.  If the inspection or access to the structure is refused by the owner/occupant and a signed waiver is obtained; 
c.  In the event that a signed waiver is not obtained, notification shall be given to the owner/occupant of his rights via certified mail, return receipt requested; 
(3)  The fire marshal's office shall be notified of any structure which has not been inspected. 
(4)  The fire marshal or his representative may at his discretion at any time he deems necessary due to specific circumstances waive, reduce or expand the area or structures required to be inspected. 
(b)  Post-blast inspections. In the event of a complaint as stated in paragraph (d), post-blast surveys shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements set forth under paragraph (a)(1) through (4) and the results filed with the fire marshal or his representative within 60 days after said completion. 
(c)  Application for blasting. 
(1)  The contractor/blaster shall complete a state approved blasting application in the fire marshal's office. An application fee set by the board of selectman shall also be submitted with said application. 
(2)  The application will be for specific locations. In a major construction project, many blasting locations may be required and each site must have a separate blasting permit. 
(3)  The contractor/blaster shall discuss the possibilities of using jack hammering or other types of less dangerous charges than dynamite with the fire marshal or his representative before the issuance of a permit and shall comply with these requirements where possible. 
(4)  The contractor/blaster shall place warning signs of impending blasting on site at least 24 hours prior to commencing blasting activity. 
(d)  Insurance requirements. 
(1)  The contractor/blaster shall provide a certificate of insurance prior to the issuance of a blasting permit. 
(2)  The insurance certificate shall provide for blaster's liability coverage and should be a specific certificate for blasting operations conducted in Seymour. 
(3)  A minimum coverage limit to be provided is $1,000,000.00 and this amount may be expanded at the fire marshal's discretion based upon the amount of blasting to be conducted and area in which it will take place. 
(e)  Blasting damage complaints. 
(1)  Any person, firm or corporation alleging personal injury or property damage as a result of blasting operations shall make a written complaint to the fire marshal or his representative. 
(2)  The complaint shall include: 
a.  Date, time, location of incident; 
b.  Description of injury or property damage; 
c.  Name, address, signature of complainant, and date of complaint; 
d.  Name of blaster/contractor (if known). 
(3)  Upon receipt of the complaint, the fire marshal or his representative shall notify and require the blaster/contractor to whom the blasting permit was issued, to pick up and sign a copy of the complaint form. 
(4)  Within 30 days of being notified, the blaster/contractor shall make a proper response to the complainant. 
(5)  The fire marshal or his representative shall conduct an investigation into the allegations made in the complaint. Upon finding that there has been a violation of this section or state regulations he may take whatever necessary to insure the public safety. 
(f)  Precautions. 
(1)  The blaster shall take special precautions in the loading, delaying, initiation and/or confinement of each blast with mats or other methods so as to control the throw of fragments, and thus prevent bodily injury or property damage. 
(2)  The blaster shall provide approved seismic instrumentation to determine the actual magnitude of ground vibration. The operation shall be operated by a qualified person and the recordings shall be interpreted by a qualified person. The instrument shall be calibrated in accordance with the manufacturers recommendation. The fire marshal or his representative may on his own initiation and the expense of the contractor/blaster, order the use of such instrumentation conducted by a professional service. 
(3)  The blaster shall abide by any other requirements as specified on the permit application by the fire marshal or his designee. These may include, but are not limited to designing the first blast to a scale distance of 70, providing extra seismic monitoring, and notification to the fire marshal prior to blasting, etc. 
(g)  Definitions. 
(1)  Structure. For the purposes of pre-blast inspection surveys, structures intended for a full inspection would be those found to be normally occupied. Other structures such as sheds, wells, inground pools, etc. shall be documented in the report as to their locations on the property being inspected. 
(h)  Penalties. Any person in violation of any of the provisions in this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in the amount not to exceed $200.00. Each day such violation continues after the time for correction of the violation has been given in an order, shall constitute a continuing violation and the amount of the fine shall be doubled for each day the violation continues, such fine not to exceed $800.00 per day. 
(Code 1061, § 12-4; Ord. of 6-15-93) 
Sec. 10-5. - Massage parlors. 
(a)  Definitions. Unless the particular provision or the context otherwise requires, the definitions and provisions contained in this subsection shall govern the construction, meaning and application of words and phrases used in this section: 
(1)  Employee means any person over 18 years of age, other than a masseur, who renders any service in connection with the operation of a massage business and receives compensation from the operator of the business or patrons. 
(2)  Massage means any method of treating the superficial parts of a patron for medical, hygienic, exercise, or relaxation purposes by rubbing, stroking, kneading, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating with the hands or any instrument, or by the application of air, liquid or vapor baths of any kind whatsoever. 
(3)  Masseur means any person who engages in the practice of massage as herein defined. The use of the masculine gender shall include in all cases the feminine gender as well. 
(4)  Patron means any person over 18 years of age who receives a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or she will pay money or give any other consideration therefor. 
(5)  Recognized school means any school or institution of learning which has for its purpose the teaching of the theory, method, profession or work of massage, which school requires a resident course of study of not less than 70 hours before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school, following the successful completion of such course of study or learning. 
(b)  Permits required: 
(1)  Business permit. No person shall engage in or carry on the business of massage unless he has a valid massage business permit issued by the town pursuant to the provisions of this section for each and every separate office or place of business conducted by such person. 
(2)  Masseur's permit. No person shall practice massage as a masseur, employee or otherwise, unless he has a valid and subsisting masseur's permit issued to him by the town pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Application for massage business permit. Any person desiring a massage business permit shall file written application with the police chief on a form to be furnished by the police chief. The applicant shall accompany the application with a tender of the correct permit fee as hereinafter provided and shall, in addition, furnish the following: 
(1)  The type of ownership of the business, i.e., whether individual, partnership, corporation or otherwise; 
(2)  The name, style, and designation under which the business or practice is to be conducted; 
(3)  The business address and all telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted; 
(4)  A complete list of the names and residence addresses of all masseurs and employees in the business, and the name and residence addresses of the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business; 
(5)  The following personal information concerning the applicant, if an individual; and concerning each stockholder holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation, each officer and each director, if the applicant is a corporation; and concerning the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and concerning the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business: 
a.  Name, complete residence address and residence telephone numbers; 
b.  The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant; 
c.  Written proof of age; 
d.  Height, weight, color of hair and eyes, and sex; 
e.  Two front-face portrait photographs taken within 30 days of the date of the application, and at least two inches by two inches in size; 
f.  The massage or similar business history and experience, including but not limited to whether or not such person in previously operating in this or another city or state under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation; 
g.  All criminal convictions other than misdemeanor traffic violation, fully disclosing the jurisdiction which convicted, and the offense for which convicted and the circumstances thereof; 
h.  A complete set of fingerprints taken and to be retained on file by the police chief or his authorized representative; 
i.  Diploma, certificate or other written proof of graduation from a recognized school by the person who shall be directly responsible for the operation and management of the massage business; 
(6)  Such other information, identification and physical examination of the person as shall be deemed necessary by the police chief to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore required to be set forth in the application; 
(7)  Authorization for the town, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the permit; 
(8)  The names and addresses of three adult residents of the county who will serve as character references. These references must be persons other than relatives and business associates; 
(9)  Written declaration by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the foregoing information contained in the application is true and correct, the declaration being duly dated and signed in the town. 
(d)  Application for masseur's permit. Any person desiring a masseur's permit shall file a written application with the police chief on a form to be furnished by the police chief. The applicant shall tender with the application the correct permit fee as hereinafter provided and shall, in addition, furnish the following: 
(1)  The business address and all telephone numbers where the massage is to be practiced; 
(2)  The following personal information concerning the applicant; 
a.  Name, complete residence address and residence telephone numbers; 
b.  The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant; 
c.  Written proof of age; 
d.  Height, weight, color of hair and eyes, and sex; 
e.  Two front-face portrait photographs taken within 30 days of the date of application and at least two inches by two inches in size; 
f.  The massage or similar business history and experience, including, but not limited to, whether or not such person in previously operating in the town or another city or state under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation; 
g.  All criminal convictions other than misdemeanors or traffic violations, fully disclosing the jurisdiction in which convicted, and the offense for which convicted and the circumstances thereof; 
h.  A complete set of fingerprints taken and to be retained on file by the police chief or his authorized representative; 
i.  Diploma, certificate, or other written proof of graduation from a recognized school where the theory, method, profession or work of massage is taught; 
j.  A statement in writing from a licensed physician in the state that he has examined the applicant and believes the applicant to be free of all communicable diseases. 
(3)  Such other information, identification, and physical examination of the person deemed necessary by the police chief in order to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore required to be set forth in the application; 
(4)  Authorization for the town, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the permit; 
(5)  Written declaration by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the foregoing information contained in the application is true and correct, the declaration being duly dated and signed in the town. 
(e)  Approval by police chief. Upon receiving the application for a massage business or masseur's permit, the police chief shall conduct an investigation into the applicant's moral character and personal and criminal history. The police chief may, in his discretion, require a personal interview of the applicant, and such further information, identification and physical examination of the person as shall bear on the investigation. In case of applications for massage business permits, the police chief shall cause to be conducted an investigation of the premises where the massage business is to be carried on, for the purposes of assuring that such premises comply with all the sanitation requirements as set forth in this section and with the regulations of public health, safety and welfare. Before any permit shall issue under this section, the police chief shall first sign his approval of the application. 
(f)  Issuance or denial of massage business permit. The police chief shall issue a massage business permit within 45 days of receipt of the application unless he finds that: 
(1)  The correct permit fee has not been tendered to the city, and, in the case of a check or bank draft, honored with payment upon presentation; 
(2)  The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the town's building, zoning, and health regulations; 
(3)  The applicant, if an individual; or any of the stockholders holding more than ten percent of stock of the corporation, any of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business, have been convicted of any crime involving dishonesty, fraud or deceit, unless such conviction occurred at least five years prior to the date of the application; 
(4)  The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent statement of fact in the permit application or in any document required by the town in conjunction therewith; 
(5)  The applicant has had a massage business, masseur, or other similar permit or license denied, revoked or suspended for any of the above causes by the town or any other state or local agency within five years prior to the date of the application; 
(6)  The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business, is not over the age of 18 years; and 
(7)  The manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business has not successfully completed a resident course of study or learning of not less than 70 hours from a recognized school where the theory, method, profession or work of massage is taught. 
(g)  Display of permits. The massage business permittee shall display his permit and that of each and every masseur employed in the establishment in an open and conspicuous place on the premises of the massage business. 
(h)  Fee. The permit fee for a massage business shall be $50.00 per year or any part thereof. The permit fee for masseurs shall be $10.00 per year or any part thereof. 
(i)  Revocation or suspension of permit. Any massage business or masseur's permit issued under this section shall be subject to suspension or revocation by the police chief for violation of any provision of this section, or for any grounds that would warrant the denial of issuance of such permit in the first place. The chief, upon such revocation or suspension, shall state his reasons in writing, specifying the particular grounds for such revocation or suspension. 
(j)  Keeping of records. Every person who operates a massage business or practices or provides a massage shall at all times keep an appointment book in which the name of each and every patron shall be entered, together with the time, date and place of service, and the services provided. Such appointment book shall be available at all times for inspection by the police chief or his authorized representatives. 
(k)  Transfers prohibited. No massage business and masseur permits are transferable, separate or divisible, and such authority as a permit confers shall be conferred only on the permittee named therein. 
(l)  Sanitation and safety requirements. All premises used by permittees hereunder shall be periodically inspected by the police chief or his authorized representatives for safety of the structure and adequacy of plumbing, ventilation, heating and illumination. The walls shall be clean and painted with washable mold-resistant paint in all rooms where water or steam baths are given. Floors shall be free from any accumulation of dust, dirt or refuse. All equipment used in the massage operation shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Towels, linen and items for personal use of operators and patients shall be clean and freshly laundered. Towels, cloths, and sheets shall not be used for more than one patron. Heavy white paper may be substituted for sheets provided that such paper is changed for every patron. No massage service or practice shall be carried on within any cubicle, room, booth or any area within a massage establishment which is fitted with a door capable of being locked. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to eliminate other requirements of statute or ordinance concerning the maintenance of premises, nor to preclude authorized inspection thereof. 
(m)  Supervision. A permittee shall have the premises supervised at all times when open for business. Any business rendering massage services shall have one person who qualifies as a masseur on the premises at all times while the establishment is open. The permittee shall personally supervise the business, and shall not violate, or permit others to violate, any applicable provision of this section. The violation of any such provision by any agent or employee of the permittee shall constitute a violation by the permittee. 
(n)  Persons under age 18 prohibited on the premises. No person shall permit any person under the age of 18 years to come or remain on the premises of any massage business establishment, as masseur, employee or patron, unless such person is on the premises on lawful business. 
(o)  Alcoholic beverages prohibited. No person shall sell, give, dispense, provide or keep or cause to be sold, given, dispensed, provided or kept any alcoholic beverage on the premises of any massage business. 
(p)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to hospitals, nursing homes, sanitariums, Y.M.C.A.s, Y.W.C.A.s, or health clubs performing similar services and providing programs similar to those of the Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A., or persons holding an unrevoked certificate to practice the healing arts under the laws of the state, or persons working under the direction of any persons or in any such establishment, nor shall this section apply to barbers or cosmetologists lawfully carrying out their particular profession or business and holding a valid, unrevoked license or certificate of registration issued by the state. 
(q)  Penalties. Any person, violating any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-9. 
Sec. 10-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Per § 2.3-21, set forth in an ordinance adopted Apr. 19, 2016, which ordinance enacted a new ch. 2.3 pertaining to adult-oriented establishments, and at the town's direction, § 10-6, pertaining to regulation of adult-oriented establishments and derived from an ordinance adopted Sept. 6, 1994, has been repealed as a conflicting provision. 
Chapter 11 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Bazaars and raffles; state statute adopted. 
    The provisions of Public Act 409 of the 1955 session of the General Assembly, entitled, "An Act Concerning Bazaars and Raffles," is hereby adopted by reference by the town. 
(Code 1961, § 13-1) 
Sec. 11-2. - Bicycles on sidewalks. 
    All bicycles are prohibited from being used on any and all sidewalks in the town. 
(Code 1961, § 13-2) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 11-3. - Fireworks-Sale prohibited. 
    No person shall sell at wholesale or retail any firecrackers or other articles of fireworks dependent for their effect upon explosion or detonation or burning within the territorial limits of the town. 
(Code 1961, § 13-3) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 11-4. - Same-Permit required for use or display. 
    No person shall use or display fireworks within the territorial limits of the town, except that organizations properly registered with the state may be permitted to use or display the same on written application to the chiefs of the police and fire departments, provided the chiefs are satisfied that a reasonably high degree of control over the same will be exercised. 
(Code 1961, § 13-4) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 11-5. - Guns and firearms-Declaration of need for regulation. 
    It is hereby declared that enactment of sections 11-5 through 11-8 is essential as a matter of public necessity and proper for protection and preservation of health, property and the lives of the citizens of the town, to protect the public safety by prohibiting the selling, or offering for sale to any person under the age of 16 years of any air gun or rifle or pistol, BB gun, spring gun, or pistol or any other implement which impels with force a pellet of any kind or any firearm to any person under the age of 16 years and further prohibiting the possession, use or carrying of such a gun or device. 
(Code 1961, § 13-6) 
Sec. 11-6. - Same-Sale to children prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and is hereby prohibited for any person to sell or offer for sale to any person under the age of 16 years any air gun or rifle or pistol, BB gun, spring gun or pistol, or rifle, or any other implement which impels with force a pellet of any kind or any gun or rifle or pistol which fires or which is designed or intended to fire a bullet, shell or pellet by means of gunpowder, or other chemical propellant which such devices are generally known as firearms, within the limits of the town. 
(Code 1961, § 13-7) 
State Law reference- Sale of pistols, revolvers to minors prohibited, G.S. § 29-34. 
Sec. 11-7. - Same-Ownership, possession, use by children prohibited; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and is hereby prohibited for any person under the age of 16 years to own, possess, use or carry any air gun or rifle or pistol, BB gun, spring gun or rifle or pistol, or any other implement which impels with force a pellet of any kind or any gun, rifle or pistol which fires or which is designed or intended to fire a bullet, shell or pellet by means of gunpowder or other chemical propellant which such devices are generally known as firearms, within the limits of the town. 
(b)  Provided, however, that a person under 16 years of age can have the use of a rifle or other device described in this section, provided they are with their parents or guardians and under their supervision. 
(Code 1961, § 13-8) 
Sec. 11-8. - Same-Confiscation by police authorized. 
    The police department is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to seize, remove and destroy any gun, rifle, pistol or implement the use of which is prescribed by the terms of sections 11-5 through 11-7. 
(Code 1961, § 13-9) 
Sec. 11-9. - Policy-Prohibited. 
    Every person who in the town, whether as principal, agent or servant, shall keep or manage or have any interest in the keeping or managing of any room, place or shop for the purpose in whole or in part of playing, conducting or carrying on or of allowing any other person to play, conduct or carry on the game, business or scheme commonly known as policy; or in part who shall write, transfer, sell, deliver, or buy in whole or in part any of the slips, tickets, tokens, numbers of chances used in or connected with such game, business or scheme of policy or who shall in any other way knowingly taken any part whatever in such game, business or scheme of policy or in any part thereof shall be fined not more than $7.00. 
(Code 1961, § 13-12) 
Sec. 11-10. - Same-Permitting use of premises for. 
    Every person owning or controlling any building, room or place who shall knowingly let, lease or permit the same to be occupied, used or resorted to for the purpose of playing, conducting or carrying on in whole or in part of the game, business or scheme commonly known as policy shall be fined not more than $7.00. 
(Code 1961, § 13-13) 
Sec. 11-11. - Same-Self-incrimination no defense in prosecution for. 
    No person summoned as a witness on the part of the state in any prosecution under either section 11-9 or 11-10 shall be excused from testifying by reason that the evidence he may give will tend to disgrace or incriminate him, nor shall he thereafter be prosecuted for anything connected with the transaction about which he shall so testify. 
(Code 1961, § 13-14) 
Sec. 11-12. - Refrigerators, airtight containers-Leaving accessible to children prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded iceboxes, refrigerators or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door or lock which may not be released for opening from the inside of the icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1961, § 13-15) 
Sec. 11-13. - Same-Removal of locks, doors required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight snap lock or any other devices therein without first removing the said snap lock or doors from said icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1961, § 13-16) 
Sec. 11-14. - Loitering. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    To loiter means standing around, moving slowly about, spending time idly, sauntering, delaying, lingering or lagging behind. 
(b)  In public areas prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on the streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, walks in public parks or any other public area so as to impede and interfere with the use of the street, sidewalk, crosswalk, walk in a public park or other public area by any other person. Any policeman may order any person violating this section to cease and desist from interfering with the right of any other person to use the streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, walks in public parks or any other public area. 
(c)  Loitering on school grounds prohibited. A person having no reason or relationship involving custody of, or responsibility for a pupil or any other license or privilege to be there, shall not loiter on school grounds within the town during school hours or during those hours from dusk through dawn unless authorized by the school administrator or his duly authorized designee. 
(d)  On private property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on private property within the town without lawful business thereon or if ordered to quit the property by the owner thereof or his agent. 
(e)  Penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount of $50.00 dollars for the first offense and $100.00 for each offense thereafter. 
(Code 1961, § 13-18; Ord. of 3-2-04(2)) 
Sec. 11-15. - Same-Operation of motor vehicles on school grounds. 
    A person not having any reason or relationship involving custody of, or responsibility for a pupil or any other license or privilege to be within said school grounds, shall not operate a motor vehicle within said school grounds. 
(Code 1961, § 13-19) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 11-16. - Damages or injury on school property. 
    Any person whether or not having license or privilege to be on school grounds who willfully or maliciously causes damage to any school property or injury to any person on such grounds shall be liable for such damage or injury. 
(Code 1961, § 13-21) 
Sec. 11-17. - Liability of parents or guardians for actions of minors. 
    The parent or parents or guardian of an unemancipated minor or minors who violate section 11-14 or 11-15 or causes injury or damage shall be jointly or severally liable as provided by section 52-572 of the general statutes. 
(Code 1961, § 13-22) 
Sec. 11-18. - Alcohol possession by minors. 
(a)  Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Alcoholic liquor shall have the same meaning, as the same term is defined in Title 30, § 30-1 of the Connecticut General Statutes as amended from time to time. 
    Host shall mean to organize a gathering of two or more persons, or to allow the premises under one's control to be used with one's knowledge for a gathering of two or more persons for personal, social or business interaction. 
    Minor shall have the same meaning, as the same term is defined in Title 30, § 30-1 of the Connecticut General Statutes as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Possession. No minor shall be in possession of alcoholic liquors, whether in opened or closed containers or otherwise, within the Town of Seymour except, when accompanied by or in the presence of his or her parent, guardian or spouse who has attained the age required to possess alcoholic liquors. These restrictions shall apply to both public and private property. 
(c)  Hosting events. No person shall host an event or gathering at which the host knowingly allows alcoholic liquor to be consumed by or dispensed to any minor unless said minor is accompanied by or in the presence of his or her parent, guardian, or spouse who has attained the age required to possess, consume or dispense alcoholic liquors. This restriction shall apply to any event or gathering within the Town of Seymour, whether conducted on public or private property. 
(d)  Penalty. Any persons violating any provision of this act shall be subject to a fine of $99.00 and any person under the age of 16 shall be referred to juvenile court. 
(Ord. of 5-1-84; Ord. of 3-2-04(3)) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 11-19. - Possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages on school property prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person within the boundaries of any school property to consume or have in his possession or control, alcoholic beverages of any kind. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, school property shall include all property under the jurisdiction of the board of education including specifically all outdoor areas as well as school buildings. 
(Ord. of 5-1-84) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 11-20. - Possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages in public parks, sidewalks, streets and other public ways prohibited. 
(a)  Prohibition. The drinking of any alcoholic liquor, as the same is defined in section 30-1 of the general statutes or in succeeding statutes, or the possession of any open container which contains alcoholic liquor is hereby prohibited in public parks, or any street, roadway, boulevard, alley, public parking lot, private parking lot for ten cars or more or sidewalk within the town. 
(b)  Exception. The board of selectmen may upon application authorize the consumption of alcoholic beverages in any public park or on any street, roadway, boulevard, alley, parking lot or sidewalk within the town, under such conditions as it shall deem appropriate for the protection of the public. Adequate police protection as prescribed by the chief of police of the town shall be provided at the sole expense of the applicant. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not more than $100.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. of 5-1-84) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; parks and recreation, Ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 11-21. - Use of burglar, fire, hold-up and automatic telephone dialer alarms. 
(a)  Short title. This section shall be known and may be cited as an ordinance regulating burglar, holdup and fire alarm systems and users. 
(b)  Purpose and definitions. 
(1)  The purpose of this section is to provide minimum standards and regulations applicable to burglar, holdup and fire alarm users as defined in this section. And to encourage the installation of protective alarm systems in all dwellings, commercial, industrial and agricultural structures. 
(2)  For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular include the plural number. The word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
Alarm agent means any person employed by an alarm business whose duties include the altering, installing, maintaining, moving, repairing, selling, servicing, responding to or causing others to respond to an alarm device. 
Alarm business means any business operated by a person for a profit which engages in the activity of altering, installing, leasing, maintaining, moving, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing or responding to a burglar, holdup or fire alarm system, or which causes any of these activities to take place. 
Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police or fire are expected to respond. In this section, the term "alarm system" shall include the terms "automatic holdup alarm system," "burglar alarm systems," "holdup alarm systems" and "manual holdup alarm systems," "alarm systems" which monitor temperature, humidity or any other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted robbery or a fire or smoke condition at a premises is to be included in this section. 
Alarm user means any person on whose premises, or property, an alarm system is maintained within the town. 
Annunciator means the instrumentation on an alarm console at the receiving terminal of a signal line which through visual and/or audible signals announces when an alarm device at a particular location has been activated or it may also indicate line trouble. 
Automatic dialing device refers to an alarm system which automatically sends, over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a pre-recorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
Burglar alarm system refers to an alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into the area protected by the system. 
Fire alarm system refers to a signal or message from a person or device indicating the existence of a fire or other emergency which requires fire department action. 
Town means the Town of Seymour, Connecticut. 
Direct connect means an alarm system which has the capability of transmitting system signals to and receiving them at an agency maintained by the local government: for example, a police communication center. 
Direct line means a telephone line leading directly to the communication center of an agency maintained by the local government that is only to report emergency signals. 
False alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. Such terminology does not include, for example, alarms caused by hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes, violent weather conditions or other acts of God. False fire alarms shall not mean alarms transmitted because of a water main break or similar causes that occur outside of the protected property. False alarms, as defined in this section, also do not include those alarms that are transmitted with a criminal, malicious or mischievous intent. 
Holdup alarm system refers to an alarm signaling a robbery or attempted robbery, in which the signal transmission is initiated by the direct action of the person attacked or by an observer of the attack. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Police chief means the chief of the police department of the Town of Seymour. 
Police or police department means the police department of the Town of Seymour. 
Fire marshal means the certified person designated as fire marshal by the Town of Seymour, or his designated representative. 
Fire department means those volunteer companies authorized by the Town of Seymour to provide fire protection services. 
Subscriber means a person who buys and/or leases, or otherwise obtains an alarm signaling system and thereafter contracts with or hires an alarm business to monitor and/or service the alarm device. 
Telephone company means the utility that furnishes telephone services to the Town of Seymour. 
(c)  Direct connections to the Seymour Police Department. Any direct line or automatic dialing device that terminates in the Seymour Police Department communications center is prohibited. 
(d)  Equipment maintenance. Each alarm user, at his expense, is required to maintain all components of the alarm system in good working order at all times to insure that the sensory mechanisms used in connection with such device be adjusted so as to suppress false indications of holdups or intrusions or fire or smoke conditions so that the device will not be activated by impulses due to short flashes of light, wind, rain, noises, vehicular noises or other forces unrelated to genuine alarms. 
(e)  Requirements. 
(1)  No alarm system shall be installed by any person other than a licensed person or other person meeting the requirements as set forth in the building and electrical codes of the state. No alarm system shall be installed unless an electrical permit to install the same has been obtained from the building official, or his designee, as required by the building and electrical codes of the state. 
(2)  All alarm systems which sound an audible signal which may be heard from the outside of the protected premises shall be equipped with a device which shall limit the duration of such audible sound to not more than 30 minutes, or to such other length of time as may be required from time to time by the state department of environmental protection. 
(f)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Enforcement and administration of this section shall be the function of the police chief, in the case of burglar and holdup alarms, and the fire marshal, in the case of fire alarms, or their designee, and shall be accomplished as provided in the following subsections. 
(2)  There are hereby imposed the following penalties upon an alarm user whose system transmits a false alarm: 
a.  For the first two false alarms within any twelve month period ..... No action 
b.  For the third such alarm ..... Written 
notice 
After the third such alarm, the alarm user will receive a written notification of the third false alarm from the police chief or fire marshal. The alarm user shall have five days from the date he receives the notification to correct the problem with the system, and shall notify the police chief or fire marshal, in writing, of such correction. The five-day period shall exclude Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. There shall be no charge for false alarms occurring within the five-day period, nor shall such alarms be considered in determining penalties in accordance with this section. 
c.  Upon receipt of the fourth false alarm, the town shall charge a penalty of $100.00 for the fourth false alarm and each false alarm thereafter, in any one calendar year. 
(3)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (f)(2), there shall be no charge for the first alarm occurring within 30 days after the installation of an alarm system and such false alarm shall not be considered in determining penalties in accordance with the schedule set forth in subsection (f)(2). 
(4)  Failure of any alarm user, and/or alarm business or alarm agent supplier, to comply with the requirements of a written notice of a violation of any provision hereof within five days of receipt of such notice, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and holidays, shall also constitute an offense punishable by a fine not to exceed $100.00. Such notice shall continue in force and effect until full compliance with requirements stated therein, and each and every failure to comply with such notice within 24 hours after the five days allowed for compliance shall constitute a separate offense, and stated fine shall be imposed for each offense. 
(g)  Alarm user identification. 
(1)  Immediately upon installation of an alarm system the police department shall be furnished, in writing, the following information: Name, address and telephone number of the alarm user and any other person authorized in an emergency to gain access to the protected area. A minimum of two names, addresses and phone numbers shall be supplied. In addition, the alarm company who installed the system, or is maintaining the system, or monitors the system, shall be supplied in accordance with this section. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of each alarm user to notify, in writing, the police department, with any changes in the list. 
(3)  Each commercial and financial institution within the town, shall notify the police department, in writing, within 30 days after the effective date of this section. 
(h)  Liability of the Town of Seymour. The town shall not be liable for any defects in operation of any signal line system, for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such source, for any failure or neglect of any person in connection with the installation, operation, disconnection or removal of equipment, the transmission of alarm signals, or the relaying of such signals or messages. 
(Ord. of 5-1-84, §§ 1-5; Ord. of 8-16-88, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 3-3-92, §§ 1-7; Ord. of 5-2-95) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 11-22. - Intentional false alarms. 
    If any person shall knowingly give a false alarm of fire in the town or knowingly proclaim that a fire is extinguished when it is not, such person, shall be fined $250.00 upon conviction. 
(Code 1961, § 9-8; Ord. of 5-2-95) 
Secs. 11-23-11-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GRAFFITI ORDINANCE 

Sec. 11-41. - Graffiti. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Graffiti. Any letters, numbers, word or words, writings or inscriptions, symbols, drawings, carvings, stickers, etchings or any other marking of any nature whatsoever which defaces, obliterates, covers, alters, damages or destroys the real or personal property of another. This chapter shall not be construed to prohibit easily removable chalk markings on public sidewalks and streets used in connection with traditional children's games. 
    Broad tipped indelible markers. Any felt marker or similar implement containing a fluid that is not water soluble and which has a flat or angled writing surface greater than a quarter of an inch wide. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. 
(1)  No person shall write, paint or place any paint, chalk or any other substance or substances or otherwise mark, scratch, place, carve or etch graffiti on the real or personal property of another, whether said real or personal property be publicly or privately owned, unless the owner of such property has specifically consented to the same, prior to the commission of such act or acts. 
(2)  No person shall carry an aerosol spray paint can or broad tipped indelible marker or other marking devices into any public building or other public facility with the intent to violate the provisions of this or any other ordinance. 
(c)  Violations and penalties. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of 100 dollars. 
(Ord. of 7-18-95) 
Sec. 11-42. - Sale of aerosol cans and markers to minors prohibited. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to deter the defacing of public and private property through the use of aerosol spray paint cans, broad tipped indelible markers and other marking devices. Within the town, the sale of such aerosol spray paint cans and broad tipped indelible markers and other marking devices to a person under 18 years of age is prohibited. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. 
(1)  No person shall sell, offer to sell, or otherwise transfer an aerosol spray paint can or broad tipped indelible marker or other marking devices to any person under 18 years of age unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian at the time of purchase. 
(2)  No person shall sell or offer for sale, or otherwise transfer an aerosol spray paint can or broad tipped indelible marker or other marking devices unless such aerosol spray paint can or indelible marker or other marking devices are held for sale or transfer in an enclosed device which is constructed to prevent removal of the merchandise except by authorized attendants or is stored out of sight in such a way as to prevent free access to the merchandise by the public. 
(c)  Violations and penalties. Any person who violates the any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of 100 dollars for each offense. In addition thereto, in the discretion of the court, such person may be directed to remove any inscription, figure or mark of any type that is painted, written or drawn upon any structure. 
(Ord. of 7-18-95) 
Sec. 11-43. - Removal of graffiti required; penalty. 
    Any person who permits graffiti to remain on his or her property for a period of more than seven days after official notification to remove same shall be subject to a fine of 100 dollars. 
(Ord. of 7-18-95) 
Sec. 11-44. - Enforcement of article and penalties generally. 
    This entire article shall be enforced by the town police department. 
(Ord. of 7-18-95) 
Chapter 12 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Parks commission, § 10.10; recreation commission, § 10.10.1. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14; zoning regulations, App. A. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for entertainment, amusements, concerts, celebrations and cultural activities, G.S. § 7-148(c)(4)(B); authority to establish, maintain, etc., parks, playgrounds, playfields, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(A)(i). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Activities within public parks and recreation areas; fine for damage. 
(a)  The parks commission shall have, subject to approval of the board of selectmen, the authority to regulate the hours during which the public parks and recreation areas shall be open. The parks commission shall set the hours of opening and closing of the parks and recreation areas and may provide for the closing of entrances and exits to said parks and recreation areas during the hours which the parks are closed. 
(b)  The use of these areas shall be limited to the residents of Seymour and their guests. 
(c)  No person shall ride on or drive any motorized two, three, or four wheeled vehicle in any park or recreation area except in places especially designated by the town. This includes, but is not limited to: snowmobiles, motorcycles, mini bikes, dirt bikes, three- and four-wheeled all-terrain vehicles, automobiles, tractors, and trucks. Parking of licensed motor vehicles is permitted only in designated areas. 
(d)  No person or vehicle shall occupy any part of the park or recreation area after hours, which the town shall post, without written permission of the town. 
(e)  No games, other than those specifically designated by the town, shall be played in any park or recreation area by any person, except in such places especially designated by the town. 
(f)  No person shall swim or bathe in any waters in said park or recreation area, except in such areas especially designated by the town. 
(g)  Hunting and trapping are prohibited in any park or recreation area. No person shall carry or discharge firearms, or any other weapon in any park or recreation area. 
(h)  No person shall use fireworks, firecrackers, or any type of explosive device in any park or recreation area, unless specific written permission is granted by the town. 
(i)  Camping is prohibited in any park or recreation area unless specific permission is granted by the town. This includes the erection of tents, cabins, or other structures. 
(j)  Ground fires are prohibited in any park or recreation area, except in places specifically designated for this purpose. Picnic tables shall not be moved from their established place. 
(k)  Disorderly conduct, use of alcohol, narcotics, and controlled substances, obscene acts, and indecent conduct is prohibited, and all forms of activity creating hazards to human safety are prohibited. 
(l)  No unauthorized person shall post or distribute any notice, sign, or advertisement within any park or recreation area. No person shall sell, or offer for sale any goods or services within any park or recreation area. No person shall solicit subscriptions, contributions, services, or play any games of chance or have in their possession any gaming instrument. 
(m)  No person shall disturb any bird, bird's nest or eggs, or any other animal within said park or recreation area, except by written permission of the town. 
(n)  No person shall dig up or remove any sand, dirt, rock, or any substance whatsoever, make any excavation, or cause or assist in doing any of said things, within any park or recreation area, except by written permission of the town. 
(o)  No person shall throw, leave, or deposit any wastepaper, bottles, remains of food, or other litter or refuse in any park or recreation area except in the receptacles provided. 
(p)  No person shall pick any flowers or cut, break, dig up, or in any manner mutilate or injure any tree, shrub, plant, grass, drive, railing, seat, fence, structure, or other public property in any park or recreation area, or cut, carve upon, mark, or paste upon any tree, stone, fence, wall, building, monument or other object contained or located in any park or recreation area, except by written permission of the town. 
(q)  Any person who shall violate any of these rules and regulations, or who shall aid or abet in the violation of any of theses rules, shall be fined a maximum of $100.00 for each offense, and be responsible for any damages incurred by said violation. 
(Code 1961, § 14-1.1; Ord. of 10-16-01(3)) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; hawkers, peddlers, vendors, canvassers and solicitors, § 10-2; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 11. 
Secs. 12-2-12-15. - Reserved.

Chapter 13 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Economic development commission, § 10.4; inland-wetlands and conservation commission, § 10.09; planning and zoning commission, § 10.11; zoning board of appeals, § 10.20. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; economic development commission to act as an advisory commission, § 2-160.2; flood damage prevention, Ch. 7; housing, Ch. 9; parks and recreation, Ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14; utilities, Ch. 17; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B; regulations for the protection and preservation of inland wetlands and water courses, App. C. 
State Law reference- Municipal planning commission, G.S. §§ 8-18-8-30a; creation of planning commissions, G.S. § 8-19; plan of development, G.S. § 8-23; requirement that municipal improvement proposals must be referred to planning commission, G.S. § 8-24; requirement that proposals concerning subdivisions of land be approved by planning commission, G.S. § 8-25; requisite of approval of subdivision plans by planning commission, G.S. § 8-26; appeals from planning commission, G.S. § 8-30; municipal redevelopment generally, G.S. §§ 8-124-8-139; authority for urban renewal projects, G.S. § 8-141; urban renewal plan, G.S. § 8-142; powers of redevelopment agency, G.S. § 8-143; powers of municipality concerning urban renewal, G.S. § 8-144; state aid for city redevelopment and urban renewal, G.S. §§ 8-151-8-162; federal aid for city redevelopment and urban renewal, G.S. §§ 8-163-8-169. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Town property exempt from planning and zoning regulations. 
    The municipal property of the town shall be exempt from the regulations of the planning and zoning commission pursuant to the provisions of section 8-2 of the general statutes; meaning hereby to exempt only such municipal property from the regulations. As to all other land not the property of the town or any of its agencies or authorities, the regulations of the planning and zoning commission are to remain in full force and effect. 
(Code 1961, § 19-6) 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. A. 
Secs. 13-2-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VALLEY COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Regional council of elected officials authorized, G.S. § 4-124c. 

Sec. 13-16. - Town authorized to join Valley Council of Governments. 
    The Town of Seymour shall be a member of the Naugatuck Valley Council of Governments in accordance with Section 4-124i through 124p, inclusive, of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Code 1961, § 6-31; Ord. of 10-16-01(4); Ord. of 6-4-14) 
Sec. 13-17. - Town's representative. 
    The representative of the town on the Naugatuck Valley Council of Governments shall be the first selectman. 
(Code 1961, § 6-32; Ord. of 6-4-14) 
Sec. 13-18. - Financial commitments. 
    Membership in the Naugatuck Valley Council of Governments shall in no way bind the town to any financial commitments or obligations except as may from time to time be provided by the annual budget meeting of the board of finance. 
(Code 1961, § 6-33; Ord. of 6-4-14) 
Sec. 13-19. - Withdrawal. 
    The town may withdraw from the Naugatuck Valley Council of Governments by repeal of this article. 
(Code 1961, § 6-34; Ord. of 6-4-14) 
Sec. 13-20. - Effect on functions of town boards or commissions. 
    Membership in the Naugatuck Valley Council of Governments shall in no way abrogate the functions of any of the town boards or commissions. 
(Code 1961, § 6-35; Ord. of 6-4-14) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, committees and agencies, § 2-21 et seq. 
Secs. 13-21-13-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOUSATONIC LAKE AUTHORITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Appointed boards, Ch. 10. 
Cross reference- Municipal flood and erosion control board, § 2-61 et seq.; flood damage prevention, Ch. 7; regulations for the protection and preservation of inland wetlands and water courses, App. C. 

Sec. 13-36. - Town participation; membership. 
(a)  Declaration. It is found and determined that it would be for the betterment of the town if the town joined the Housatonic Lake Authority and participated in the activities of the authority as provided in section 7-151A of the general statutes. 
(b)  Membership in authority. It is hereby enacted and ordained that the town join and be a member of the Housatonic Lake Authority. There shall be a three-member delegation to the authority from the town. 
(Code 1961, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-37. - Appointment of members, terms. 
    The members of the Housatonic Lake Authority shall be appointed by the first selectman in the instance of the initial appointment; one for a term of three years, one for a term of two years and one for a term of one year and thereafter all members shall be appointed for a term of three years. 
(Code 1961, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-38. - Duties. 
(a)  The Housatonic Lake Authority shall act as agent for the town in cooperating with the state boating commission in the enforcement of the boating laws on bodies of water within the territorial limits of the town. 
(b)  The Housatonic Lake Authority shall be granted the power within the bodies of water within the territorial limits of the town to: 
(1)  Control and abate algae and aquatic weeds in cooperation with the state water resource commission in accordance with the general statutes; 
(2)  Study water management including but not limited to water depth and circulation and make recommendation for action to its member towns; 
(3)  Act as agent for the town with respect to filing applications for grants and reimbursement with the department of environmental protection and other state agencies in connection with state and federal programs; and 
(4)  Act as agent for the town with respect to receiving gifts for any of its purposes. 
(Code 1961, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-39. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the town's delegation to the Housatonic Lake Authority shall be filled by appointment of the first selectman. 
(Code 1961, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-40. - Applicability of state statutes. 
    The method of withdrawal from the Housatonic Lake Authority shall be governed by section 7-101A of the general statutes. The authority will be operated under provision of section 7-151A of the general statutes. 
(Code 1961, § 2-18) 
Secs. 13-41-13-55. - Reserved.

(Code 1961, § 2-10)

ARTICLE V. - OPEN SPACE ADVISORY BOARD[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance of Nov. 14, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ A-C of such ordinance as Art. V, §§ 13-81-13-83, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 13-81. - Created; responsibilities generally. 
    There is hereby created an open space advisory board which shall be responsible for advising the board of selectmen concerning the maintenance and development of open space within the town. 
(Ord. of 11-14-89, § A) 
Sec. 13-82. - Composition; terms; appointments. 
    The composition of the board shall be as follows: one member from the board of selectmen; one member from the planning and zoning commission; one member from the zoning board of appeals; one member from the Seymour Land Trust; one member from the parks commission; one member from the inland wetlands commission; and one member-at-large from the public. Each member shall be appointed for a term of one year and shall serve until his successor has been appointed. Each appointment shall be an administrative appointment of the first selectman. 
(Ord. of 11-14-89, § C) 
Sec. 13-83. - Advisory duties. 
    The open space advisory board shall collect and distribute information to the board of selectmen concerning the development of land within the town which is used by the town as open space and for passive recreation. The board shall consult with the board of selectmen and make recommendations to the board of selectmen concerning the maintenance and development of said land. Final decisions concerning said maintenance and development shall rest with the board of selectmen and other town boards and commissions empowered to act by Charter and town ordinances. 
(Ord. of 11-14-89, § B) 
Chapter 14 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of board of selectmen to accept or abandon town roads, § 7.2(e); power to take, purchase, lease, sell or convey real estate, § 7.2(b); board of public works, § 10.13. 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 8; bicycles on sidewalks prohibited, § 11-2; possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages on school property prohibited, § 11-19; possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages in public parks, sidewalks, streets, etc., prohibited, § 11-20; parks and recreation, Ch. 12; planning, Ch. 13; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 16; utilities, Ch. 17; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 
State Law reference- Power of town to control the excavation of the highways and streets, G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(iii); to lay out construct, etc., streets, sidewalks, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(i); to provide for lighting the streets, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(4)(F); to provide for the planting, etc., of shade and ornamental trees on the streets and public grounds, G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(A)(v); to keep open, etc., the streets, sidewalks, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(ii); to require owners or occupants of land adjacent to any sidewalk to remove snow, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(v); to regulate and prohibit the excavation, etc., of sidewalks, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(C)(iv); to prohibit and regulate the discharge of drains from roofs of buildings over or upon the sidewalks, streets, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(B)(iv); to keep the streets, sidewalks and public places free from undue noises and nuisances, etc., G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(F)(i); highways and bridges, G.S. § 13a-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Trimming of trees overhanging highway. 
    The selectmen are ordered to notify persons having shade or other trees that have branches or limbs hanging over the highway to trim them off to a height above any passing vehicle. If not so trimmed the selectmen shall cause the same to be done. 
(Code 1961, § 17-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Notice of intent to request streetlights. 
    Any party desiring electric lights placed on any street in the town shall notify the selectmen at least ten days before the resolution will be presented at any town meeting. 
(Code 1961, § 17-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Height of awning over sidewalks. 
    All awnings shall be not less than seven feet above the sidewalk. 
(Code 1961, § 17-3) 
Sec. 14-4. - Construction and repair of sidewalks or curbs-Selectmen authorized to order. 
    The board of selectmen shall have authority as public convenience and necessity may require, to order sidewalks or curbs to be constructed or repaired. 
(Code 1961, § 17-4) 
Sec. 14-5. - Same-Supervision by selectmen; assessments for. 
    Whenever any sidewalk or curb shall be ordered constructed or repaired by the selectmen the work shall be done under the selectmen's supervision in a thorough and workmanlike manner and as economically as possible. The width, height, level, grade and material shall be determined by the selectmen. The selectmen shall then assess not to exceed two-thirds of the expense thereof against the person or property adjoining. Such sums assessed shall be ordered paid into the town treasury and if not paid within 30 days after notice is given, a lien shall be placed upon the premises adjoining such walk and shall be recorded in the town clerk's office within 60 days after completion. 
(Code 1961, § 17-5) 
Sec. 14-6. - Removal of ice, snow from sidewalks. 
(a)  The provisions of Section 7-163a, C.G.S. are hereby adopted and are set forth in subsections (b), (c), (d) and (e) hereof. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 13a-149, C.G.S. or any other general or special act, the town shall not be liable to any person for injury to person or property caused by the presence of ice or snow on a public sidewalk unless the town is the owner or person in possession and control of land abutting such sidewalk, other than land used as a highway or street, provided that the town shall be liable for its affirmative acts with respect to such sidewalk.
