(c)  The owner or person in possession and control of land abutting a public sidewalk shall have the same duty of care with respect to the presence of ice or snow on such sidewalk toward the portion of the sidewalk abutting his property as the town had prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section and shall be liable to persons injured in person or property where a breach of said duty is the proximate cause of said injury. 
(d)  No action to recover damages for injury to person or property caused by the presence of ice or snow on a public sidewalk against a person who owns or is in possession and control of land abutting a public sidewalk shall be brought but within two years from the date when the injury is first sustained. 
(e)  Whenever the public sidewalk shall be wholly or partially covered by snow or ice, it shall be the duty of the owner or person in possession and control of land abutting a public sidewalk to cause such sidewalk to be made safe and convenient by removing the snow therefrom within the first six hours of daylight immediately following the accumulation of such snow thereon or, in the case of ice, by covering the same with sand or other suitable material within the first six hours of daylight following the accumulation of such ice, and then renewing such treatment as often as may be necessary to keep such sidewalk safe and convenient. In case of the failure or neglect of the owner or person in possession and control of land abutting the public sidewalk to comply with this subsection, the selectman may cause the same to be done, and the expense thereof shall be collectible from the person so failing or neglecting. Any person who fails or neglects to comply with this subsection shall also be liable for a penalty or fine in an amount established in accordance with section 1-9, general penalty. 
(Code 1961, § 17-6; Ord. of 3-18-97; Ord. of 7-21-15(3)) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 14-7. - Acceptance of streets. 
(a)  Generally. The procedures set forth in this section shall be followed in the acceptance of all streets, highways or public ways in the town other than streets of record as of October 11, 1956. 
(b)  Conformity to regulations. All proposed streets shall be laid out, graded and constructed their entire length and full width, from street line to street line, in full accordance with the following specifications and these regulations and modes of procedure and any amendments thereto. 
(c)  Establishment of lines and grades. The owner shall engage the services of a registered engineer or surveyor to lay out the lines and grades of the streets, their entire width and length. 
(d)  Width. In accordance with such approved lines and grades the owner shall construct a roadway at least 30 feet wide centered between the street lines in the case of a 50-foot highway and at least 36 feet wide in the case of a 60-foot highway, having a crown of not more than eight inches as the selectmen or their representative may direct. No road shall be accepted unless it is at least 50 feet in width. 
(e)  Sidewalk shoulders. The shoulders of sidewalk areas shall be graded to the centerline grade at the gutter line and have a pitch of not more than one-half inch to the foot toward said gutter line from the street line. The slopes shall start at the street lines. 
(f)  Grade. The percentage of grade shall not be less than one percent or more than ten percent except that if in the opinion of the selectmen or the zoning and planning commission, these limits cause undue hardship, they may allow grades in excess of ten percent provided no appreciable hazard to health or safety is thereby created. 
(g)  Excavation depth; slope; subgrade. All sod and other vegetable matter shall be excavated and stumps removed where fills of less than four feet are made. Boulders and ledges shall be removed to a depth of at least 12 inches below finished grade. Slopes in cut or fill shall not be steeper than one on two and shall be neatly graded. The subgrade shall be brought to a uniform surface, the grade of which shall be inspected and approved by the selectmen or their representative before the surfacing may be done. 
(h)  Surfacing. Upon the proposed subgrade shall be spread a uniform gravel or broken stone surface which shall have a minimum depth after compaction of eight inches except, where ledge rock is encountered, the depth shall be increased to 12 inches after compaction. All surfacing materials shall be approved prior to placing by the selectmen or their representative. The finished surface shall be thoroughly compacted by wetting and rolling and shall be uniformly graded to the required cross-section. Upon this prepared surface there shall be spread a coating of MC1 road oil at the rate of three-fourths of a gallon per square yard. This coating shall be allowed to set and traffic shall not be allowed to use the roadway until the selectmen or their representative shall have determined that the oil has properly set. A seal coat of MC3 road oil shall be applied at the rate of not more than one-half of a gallon per square yard and shall be immediately covered with clean sand in sufficient quantity to prevent bleeding and picking up of the bitumen before traffic is allowed to use the roadway. 
(i)  Storm drains. All storm drains determined by the selectmen or their representative to be required by good construction practice and in a manner approved by the selectmen or their representative shall be constructed by the owner or developer at his sole expense. The storm drains shall include all necessary pipelines, catch basins, manholes and appurtenances sufficient and adequate to provide proper drainage. Wherever, in the opinion of the selectmen or their representative, the grades will cause excessive erosion, and at all catch basins, gutters shall be paved with bituminous concrete. 
(j)  Inspection and approval during construction. The construction on all the above improvements shall always be subject to inspection by the selectmen or their duly appointed representatives. No subgrades, storm or sanitary sewers, drains, culverts or bridge work shall be covered until inspected and approved, nor shall the gravel surface be oiled until inspected and approved. 
(k)  Location monuments. Reinforced concrete monuments of 1:2:4 mix, four inches square at the top, six inches square at the bottom and three feet long shall be set at angle points, points of curve and other critical or control points to define and locate the street rights-of-way. Each monument shall have a brass or iron rod at least six inches long in the top and shall be the point of reference. The tops of the monuments shall be set to the established grade. The monuments shall be set in place after all other street improvements are completed. The accuracy of location of such monuments shall be certified in writing by the land surveyor or engineer making the street layout before the acceptance of such street by the town. 
(l)  Final acceptance. Upon completion of the required improvements as set forth in this section including the setting of all monuments, the construction of all roads and the installation of all required drainage facilities and upon certification by the selectmen or their representative of the same in writing, the street shall be accepted by the town. 
(Code 1961, § 17-10) 
Sec. 14-8. - Acceptance of private roads as public highways. 
    No private road may be accepted as a public highway except in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Compliance with specifications; improvements. Upon approval of the acceptance of the private road by a town meeting warned for the purpose, the abutting owners or developer shall grade, surface and drain the private road in accordance with the specifications set forth in section 14-7; provided, however, the specifications may be waived by the board of selectmen where compliance would be impracticable or impose undue hardship upon the abutting owners and, in such event, the town shall make such improvements as shall be necessary to render the highways safe for public travel. 
(2)  Acceptance. Upon completion of such improvements certified to the town clerk in writing by the board of selectmen, the road shall become a public highway. 
(3)  Additional standards. No private road may become a public highway under this section unless is existed on October 11, 1956 and has occupied homes thereon at time of application. 
(Code 1961, § 17-11) 
Sec. 14-9. - Deposit of snow or ice on public street forbidden. 
(a)  No person shall plow, throw, deposit, place or cause to be thrown, deposited or placed any snow or ice on any public roadway or sidewalk in the town. 
(b)  Any owner, occupant or person having charge of premises violating any provisions of this section shall be fined in accordance with section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 3-18-97) 
Sec. 14-10. - Street names. 
    The board of selectmen shall have the exclusive right to name and re-name streets in the town, after review of the proposed street name(s) by the emergency services committee. 
(Ord. of 6-29-98) 
Secs. 14-11-14-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET EXCAVATIONS, ETC.[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted July 19, 2015, effectively repealed the former art. II, §§ 14-21-14-23, and enacted a new art. II as set out herein. The former art. II pertained to excavations and derived from Code 1961, §§ 17-8, 17-9; an ordinance adopted Dec. 6, 1994; and an ordinance adopted Oct. 21, 2008. 
Cross reference- Sewer construction permits, § 17-51 et seq. 

Sec. 14-21. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Engineer means the town engineer or his duly authorized representative. 
    Inspector means the town engineer or his duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-22. - Permission of town required; unauthorized excavations, etc., may be closed, etc., by town. 
(a)  No person shall excavate within or under, or place any obstruction or substruction within, under, upon or over any town highway without direct permission of the town engineer. If any person shall violate the provisions of this section the town may, at its option, fill in or close any such excavation or remove or alter the same and the expense incurred by the town in such filling or removing or altering shall be paid by the person making such excavation or placing such obstruction or substruction. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be punished as provided by section 14-35.13. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-23. - Permit-Generally. 
(a)  The town engineer is hereby authorized and empowered to grant a permit for excavation or obstruction or substruction of any town roadway, subject to the provisions of this article. The authorization given by such engineer for such use of the highway shall be in writing in a form prescribed by him, which form is designated and known as a "permit." Such permit shall be issued on a multi-copy form prepared by the town engineer. A copy of all such permits issued by the town engineer shall be forwarded to the director of public works. In appropriate cases where the excavation shall substantially interfere with traffic or cause any highway to become completely impassable, the engineer shall also forward copies of such permit to the chief of police and to the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  Any applicant seeking a permit to perform work on a state highway must get a street opening permit from the town before applying for a state permit. This section will not supersede any regulations as set forth by the state department of transportation in regards to excavation in state highways. 
(c)  When issuing a permit on any highway that has been reconstructed or resurfaced within five years of the date of the permit application, the town reserves the right to designate the patch limits and requirements, which may include curb-to-curb milling and overlay of the affected area, at a minimum. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-24. - Same-Application, etc., generally. 
    An application, in writing, in a form prescribed by the engineer shall be made to the engineer at least five days prior to the time any excavation or obstruction for which a permit is required by the provisions of this article is to be commenced. The engineer may require a sketch of such proposed work, drawn to scale if he finds the same is necessary. The engineer may, in his discretion, extend the time limitation specified in this section or in any other section of this article. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-25. - Same-Rejection of applications. 
    When it appears that the work called for in an application required by section 14-24 would cause substantial or needless damage to a highway or create excessive disturbance to traffic or exceptionally dangerous conditions not commensurate with the benefits to the applicant, the request for such permit may be denied. The applicant will be informed of such rejection by letter from the engineer, stating the reasons for such rejection. The engineer shall reject the application of any person when such applicant has failed to perform work under a previously issued permit within the time required or in the manner required or when the applicant has failed to reimburse the town for recoverable charges billed under the terms governing a previous permit. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-26. - Same-Fees generally; engineer's monthly statement. 
    The engineer shall collect the sum of $150.00 for each permit issued by him under the provisions of this article. Such sum shall be payable prior to the time the permit is issued. All sums of money collected by the engineer shall be paid by him to the town treasurer on a monthly basis. The engineer shall submit a monthly statement to the finance department itemizing permit, inspection and patching fees collected during the month. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-27. - Same-Town work. 
    No contractor or subcontractor performing work directly for the town or any of its agencies or instrumentalities shall be required to pay any permit fee as provided for in section 14-26. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-28. - Same-Emergency permits generally. 
    Emergency permits may be granted by the engineer or by the inspector, in the case of broken gas or water mains or other such emergencies, but the person performing such excavation or creating such obstruction shall file a written application for a permit within 24 hours thereafter, in the manner prescribed by this article for non-emergency work. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-29. - Same-Emergency work. 
    When the town, or any of its agencies or instrumentalities, or any contractor or subcontractor performing work directly for the town or any of its agencies or instrumentalities, shall notify the engineer or the inspector that there is immediate need for any excavation or obstruction, or, in the case of redevelopment construction or demolition, that work must be performed immediately, the engineer or inspector shall grant an emergency permit as provided in section 14-28. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-30. - Same-Revocation of permit. 
    Any permit issued by the engineer pursuant to the provisions of this article is revocable immediately upon written notification or oral order given personally to the permittee by the engineer or inspector. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-31. - Bond or deposit required. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the engineer to determine the amount of the guarantee to be deposited with the town by the permittee in connection with each permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. He may accept either a certified or bank check or a surety bond with good and sufficient surety. Such bond to be in a form prescribed by the town counsel. No permit shall be issued until such deposit or bond has been filed with the engineer. An annual blanket surety bond, acceptable to the town counsel, may be deposited to avoid the inconvenience and expense of obtaining individual deposits or bonds for each permit requested. The engineer shall release such deposit or surety bond six months after the permanent top surface has been installed by either the town or the permit holder; provided, however, that such deposit or bond shall not be released unless all of the requirements of this article have been met. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-32. - Insurance required. 
    The applicant for a permit under the provisions of this article shall, before issuance of such permit, deliver to the town engineer an insurance policy written by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state, upon which the town is a named insured, which policy shall insure against bodily injury or property damage arising out of any action or activity or work of the applicant in connection with the work undertaken under such permit. Such policy shall have bodily injury and property damage limits of $1,000,000.00 minimum per each occurrence and shall have a $2,000,000.00 minimum general aggregate limit. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-33. - Time for performance. 
(a)  All work performed under the provisions of this article shall be completed in a manner satisfactory to the engineer before the expiration date established by the engineer which shall be shown on the permit. The permit holder may request the engineer to allow an extension of time. The extension of time may be granted in writing by the engineer. 
(b)  The inspector shall be notified at least 24 hours in advance of actually starting any work authorized under a permit. Failure of the permittee to notify the town will result in the revocation of the permit. Permits are void three months after their issue date. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-34. - Inspection. 
    The engineer or his agent is empowered to inspect all excavations for workmanship and materials. The excavations may not be permanently backfilled without the engineer or his agent, i.e. inspector, present at the site. The town will require the permittee to excavate and expose for inspection any portion of the excavation backfilled without inspection or authorization to backfill. The permittee shall be responsible for the payment of the hourly rate, as determined by the engineer, of the inspector for the time in which the inspector is observing the backfilling of the excavation. An estimate of the required inspector's time will be made and paid for at the time of permit application. In the event the actual inspection time exceeds the estimated time, the permittee shall pay the additional fee to the town within ten working days. Failure to pay said additional fee will result in the permittee forfeiting any rights to future permits until the outstanding balance is received. The town may, at its discretion, use the proceeds from the bond required in section 14-31 to pay any amounts due to the town. In the event that the actual inspection time is less than the estimated time the town will promptly refund any overcharge to the permittee. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35. - Traffic protection. 
    It shall be the duty of every permittee under this article to make certain that the security of the travelling public is safeguarded and its rights are not unreasonably curtailed. If any excavation or obstruction shall be left upon any highway at night it shall be marked by flares, lanterns, lights, flashing beacons or other warning devices approved by the engineer. If the work performed under the highway shall make the travelled portion dangerous for the movement of vehicles, a sufficient number of watchmen, flagmen or police officers, as determined by the traffic authority, shall be assigned by the permittee to direct traffic. The cost of all watchmen, flagmen or police officers shall be the responsibility of the permittee. In the event the work of the permittee requires the closing of a public highway for any period of time, the permittee shall give written notice to the police department and the director of public works or his designated representative 24 hours in advance of any required closing. The director may determine the need for closing the highway and may require the work or work method be so altered so as to provide for traffic flow. The town engineer or the director of public works, or his agent, shall provide written notice to the police and fire departments in advance of closing any public highway. Any permittee who leaves an excavation in an unsafe condition or abandons a street opening shall be liable for all costs incurred by the town to correct such conditions. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.1. - Protection of tree roots. 
    The greatest care shall be exercised by persons performing work under the provisions of this article to protect tree roots from damage, not only when excavating but on all subsequent operations of construction and backfilling. When roots are encountered near the base of a tree the permittee shall tunnel under the roots as directed by the inspector. The inspector may require such other protection as shall be reasonable in regard to any particular instance. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.2. - Opening of pavement. 
    The pavement surface shall be removed with all edges cut to a neat, straight line, preferably cut with a concrete saw; however, such cutting can be accomplished with a spade point tool. Under no circumstances shall the pavement slab be subject to blows from a hammer or dropweight, but any concrete base or subbase under the pavement slab may be broken with a pneumatic tool using a bullpoint. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.3. - Size of excavation; placement of excavated material. 
    The size of the excavation shall be kept as small as practicable to carry on the work. No material removed in excavating shall be placed in the travelled path unless approved by the inspector. In any case, the material shall be placed so as to interfere as little as possible with the ordinary use of the highway. If such excavated material must be placed in gutters, suitable conduits first shall be installed temporarily in which to carry drainage beyond the obstruction. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.4. - Blasting. 
    When rock or other hard material must be removed by a permittee under this article, he may blast such material if the pavement or other structures will not be endangered thereby. Only a "blast man" licensed by the Commissioner of Emergency Services and Public Protection will be permitted to charge or set off blasts within the highway right-of-way. All state and municipal regulations concerning the same shall be fully complied with. The permittee shall be responsible for all damage. A mat or weight of logs or sand bags shall be placed over the charge to prevent shattered materials from scattering. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.5. - Tunneling or jacking. 
    Tunneling or jacking shall be permitted only when plans prepared by a registered engineer are submitted to and approved by the town engineer. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.6. - Backfilling. 
    Backfill in trenches within paved areas shall be placed in layers not more than 12 inches thick and shall be thoroughly compacted by tamping or other approved means to the satisfaction of the inspector. Compaction equipment shall be at the excavation site and must be utilized during all backfilling operations. The material used for backfill shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the inspector, and if in his opinion, the excavated material is unsuitable for backfill, the permittee shall be required to dispose of the unsuitable materials and replace them with materials that are suitable to the inspector. When backfill has been completed within 15 inches of the finished pavement or surface grade, the next 14 inches shall be filled and compacted, in two seven-inch layers, using an approved grade of bank-run gravel or processed aggregate. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.7. - Temporary patch. 
    As soon as the excavation has been backfilled and compacted, the pavement shall be replaced temporarily by the permittee. The temporary pavement shall consist of bituminous concrete, of a mixture approved by the inspector (ConnDOT Class 2), compressed to a minimum depth of two inches. The surface of the temporary pavement shall be flush at the edge of the existing pavement and extend above the surface of the surrounding permanent pavement by one inch in the center of the patch and shall be reasonably smooth. The permittee shall be responsible for the temporary pavement and shall see that the contractor or his own forces keep this pavement in repair until the permanent surface can be replaced by the town. Additional material shall be added by the permittee, as necessary, as the backfill settles. If the permittee does not maintain the temporary pavement adequately, the engineer may direct that necessary repairs be made by the department of public works to prevent accidents and the permittee will be charged by the town for this work. Failure on the part of the town to give notice that repairs are needed shall not relieve the contractor of any of the duties set forth herein. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.8. - Permanent patch. 
    The permanent repair of street openings shall be the responsibility of the town, except in the case of a particularly large or difficult project, in which case the engineer may require that the permittee be responsible for installation of the permanent patch. The town shall charge each permittee a fee for the cost of said permanent patch based on the area of the final patch as calculated by the engineer. The permanent patch shall be a minimum of two feet wider and two feet longer than the temporary patch. A permanent patch size will be estimated and paid for at the time of permit application. In the event the actual size of the permanent patch exceeds the estimated size of permanent patch, the permittee shall pay the additional fee to the town within ten working days. Failure to pay said additional fees will result in the permittee forfeiting any rights to future permits until the outstanding balance is received. The town may, at its discretion, use the proceeds from the bond required in section 14-31 to pay any amounts due to the town. In the event that the actual permanent patch is smaller than the estimated size of the permanent patch, the town will promptly refund any overcharge to the permittee. The unit prices charged for the installation of the permanent patch shall be determined by the engineer in accordance with current costs and construction practices. The engineer shall advertise for bids for the permanent patching of town streets in accordance with specifications prepared by the engineer every two years. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.9. - Resurfacing. 
    When issuing a permit on any highway that has been reconstructed or resurfaced within five years of the date of the permit application, the town reserves the right to designate the patch limits and requirements, which may include curb-to-curb milling and overlay of the affected area, plus an additional five feet on each end, at a minimum. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.10. - Reconstruction of curbs and sidewalks. 
    Every permittee under the provisions of this article shall reconstruct all curbs and sidewalks disturbed by any excavation made by him with materials similar to those of which they were originally constructed. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.11. - Removing manhole covers. 
    No person shall remove any manhole cover from any manhole owned or operated by the town without first securing the permission of the engineer to do so. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.12. - Termination of permit. 
    Six months after installation of the temporary patch, the permittee shall apply in writing for termination of the permit and release from any obligation involved thereafter. If in the opinion of the engineer or his agent the work is not satisfactorily completed or settlement is occurring, necessary repairs shall be undertaken by the permittee and an additional period of liability shall be established by the engineer or his agent. The installation of a permanent patch by the town to said opening shall terminate the permit and release the permittee from any obligations thereafter. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.13. - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not more than $500.00 for a first offense and $1,000.00 for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
Sec. 14-35.14. - Appeals. 
    Any person, firm or corporation aggrieved by the imposition of a fine under section 14-35.13 shall have the right to appeal to the board of selectmen the imposition of said fine in writing. The appeal shall state the reasons why the fine should not be imposed. The board of selectmen's decision in said case shall be final. 
(Ord. of 7-19-2016(3)) 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 14-36. - Permit required. 
    No construction, alteration, or repairs shall be performed on any sidewalk, curb, or driveway, paved or otherwise within the public right of way of the town until all necessary permits have been obtained in accordance with sections 14-21 and 14-22. A grade line shall be obtained from the office of the town engineer after a permit has been obtained and before construction begins. 
(Code 1961, § 17-16; Ord. of 1-5-99) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 14-37. - Regulations. 
    The following regulations shall apply to curbs, sidewalks, and driveways: 
(1)  All curbs shall be constructed of concrete, granite, or machine formed bituminous concrete. Location and elevation shall be specified by the town engineer. 
(2)  Sidewalks shall be constructed and located in accordance with the land subdivision regulations of the town, except that sidewalks on existing streets shall be constructed or reconstructed in accordance with section 14-5 of this chapter. 
(3)  The number of driveways per lot, location, grade and other design standards shall be specified in the zoning regulations of the town. 
(4)  The driveway apron shall be paved with at least a two inch layer of class II bituminous concrete underlayment by at least eight inches of subbase. The driveway lip, or the vertical rise at the curb line, shall be two inches. 
(5)  When a driveway crosses a watercourse, culvert, or other drainage structure designed for at least a 25 year storm shall be provided. Drainage structures shall be designed and installed to bear a minimum weight of 55,000 pounds. 
(6)  The following shall apply to driveways serving more than one principal building: 
a.  The street address of each building served by the driveway shall be indicated by numbers at least three inches high where the driveway meets the town road. 
b.  The address of each building shall be indicated by numbers at least three inches high affixed to the building. 
c.  If a common driveway divides, the direction to each structure shall be clearly shown at the point of division. 
(7)  All phases of work involved in the construction and repair of curbs, sidewalks, and driveway aprons shall be subject to inspection by the department of public works, and the town engineer. 
(8)  Definitions: 
Apron. The driveway apron is that portion of a driveway between the curb line and the street line or front lot line and within the town right of way. 
Construction materials. All construction materials cited herein shall conform to CT DOT Standard Specifications for Roads, Bridges, and Incidental Construction, latest edition. 
(Code 1961, § 17-17; Ord. of 1-5-99) 
Chapter 15 - TAXATION AND FINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Finance and taxation, § 12.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Assessments for flood or erosion control system, § 2-65 et seq.; assessor, § 2-181 et seq.; finance director, § 2-211 et seq.; employee benefits, § 2-226 et seq.; purchasing and selling, § 2-251 et seq. 
State Law reference- Taxation, G.S. Title 12. 

Sec. 15-1. - Payments by tax collector to treasurer. 
    The collector of town taxes shall pay all moneys received by him over to the treasurer on or before the fifth day of each month. 
(Code 1961, § 8-1) 
State Law reference- Duty of collector to pay receipts to treasurer on or before the fifth of each month, G.S. § 12-147. 
Sec. 15-2. - Records of indebtedness and payments to be kept by treasurer. 
    The town treasurer shall keep a true and perfect registry of all notes or bonds issued in a book kept for that purpose stating the date, the amount and the person to whom the bond or note is given, the date and amount of interest paid thereon and the name of the holder of the note or bond at the time of such payment. 
(Code 1961, § 8-2) 
Sec. 15-2.5. - Retention of overpayment of property taxes. 
    The Tax Collector of the Town of Seymour is authorized to retain property tax overpayments in excess of the amount due provided the amount of the excess payment is less than $5.00. 
(Ord. of 10-16-01(5); Ord. of 4-20-04(3) 
Sec. 15-3. - Sale of property acquired for taxes. 
    The board of selectmen are hereby authorized and empowered to sell whatever property the town has acquired or may acquire by tax foreclosure on such terms as they may deem to be in the best interests of the town. The board of selectmen shall publish in the local paper a list of the properties to be sold. 
(Code 1961, § 8-3) 
Sec. 15-4. - Disposition of revenue from tax sales. 
    All proceeds received for any property which the town acquires, including conveyances in lieu of taxes or by foreclosure, shall be turned over to the tax collector, who shall apply said proceeds to the payment of the expenses involved, and the taxes for which the property was taken, and if any balance is left, it shall be turned over to the town treasurer. 
(Code 1961, § 8-4) 
Sec. 15-5. - Tax abatement. 
    Pursuant to section 12-81b of the general statutes; retroactively to October 1, 1975, any tax-exempt organization as defined by the general statutes subsections (7) to (16) inclusive, of section 12-81, may upon written request to the board of selectmen, request an abatement of the amount paid by the tax-exempt buyer to the private seller, prorated as of the recorded date of the sale, to cover taxes paid by the private seller to the town. The board of selectmen shall make a written request to the tax assessor for the computation of the prorated abatement as of the recorded date of sale. The board of selectmen shall then authorize the tax collector to issue a check to the tax-exempt organization in the amount of the prorated abatement. 
(Code 1961, § 8-5) 
Sec. 15-6. - Property tax abatement for solar energy systems. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 12-81 of the general statutes, the board of selectmen shall grant a property tax exemption for any building or addition to a building, the construction of which is commenced on or after October 1, 1976, and before October 1, 1991, which is equipped with a solar energy heating or cooling system, to the extent of the amount by which the assessed valuation of such real property equipped with such solar heating or cooling system exceeds the excess valuation of such real property with the conventional portion of the heating or cooling system exclusive of any portion of such system related to solar energy, provided this exemption shall apply to only the first 15 assessment years following construction of such building or addition. 
(b)  An addition to a building shall mean the solar energy heating or cooling system which is added to a building which was constructed or under construction prior to October 1, 1976. The building inspector shall verify the legitimacy of such systems and the assessor shall, with the advise of the building inspector, determine the exact amount that the system adds to the value of the building. 
(Code 1961, § 8-6) 
Sec. 15-7. - Water main assessments. 
(a)  The board of selectmen is hereby designated as the authority with all powers and duties to administer any extension of water mains as provided in section 7-137c of the general statutes. The tax collector shall be the collection agency of any assessments made by the board of selectmen by virtue of action taken under section 7-137c or section 7-137d of the general statutes. 
(b)  Any assessment levied by the board of selectmen shall comply with the statutory requirements of section 7-137c of the general statutes and the assessments against each owner of property which is capable of being served by the water main and which abuts such water main shall not exceed this special benefit to such property. Such assessments may be levied at any time, but shall not be payable until the property assessed has the availability of water. The board of selectmen may allow such assessments to be paid in installments over a period not exceeding 20 years or such lesser period as the board of selectmen shall determine, and the board of selectmen shall fix the rate of interest to be paid on the outstanding balance of the installments. The board of selectmen is hereby delegated the authority to determine the particulars of such assessments and to determine the notices to be given to such property owners against whom assessments are levied and for providing for the payment and collection of such assessments. 
(Ord. of 10-6-81; Ord. of 12-6-94(5)) 
Charter reference- General powers and duties of the board of selectmen, § 7.1. 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 15-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance of September 6, 1994, repealed section 15-8 in its entirety. Former § 15-8 derived from an ordinance of January 23, 1984 and pertained to budget expenditure. 
Sec. 15-9. - Authorization to waive tax bill less than $5.01. 
(a)  Title. This section, which shall be known as "Authorization to waive tax bill less than $5.01," is adopted pursuant to the provisions of Connecticut General Statute § 12-144(c) as amended. 
(b)  Waiver. The board of selectmen is hereby authorized and empowered to waive any property tax due to the town in an amount less than $5.01, provided it takes such action before the tax due date. 
(Ord. of 11-19-02(3)) 
Sec. 15-10. - Tax exemption for motor vehicles equipped for disabled persons. 
(a)  Title. This section, which shall be known as "Tax Exemption for Motor Vehicles Equipped for Disabled Persons," is adopted pursuant to the provisions of Connecticut General Statutes § 12-81c(3). 
(b)  Definitions. 
    Person with disabilities means an individual who has a physical impairment or impairments which substantially limit major life activities, such as seeing, hearing, speaking, walking, breathing, performing manual tasks, learning, caring for oneself, and working. However, an individual with a minor non-chronic condition or a condition with a short duration shall not be considered to be person with disabilities for the purpose of this ordinance. 
    The phrase "any motor vehicle owned by a person with disabilities, or owned by the parent or guardian of such person, which vehicle equipped for purposes of adapting its use to the disability of such person" means any vehicle equipped with special hand, foot or hand and foot controls, wheelchair lifts or hoists, or other adaptation to assist physically disabled drivers, which is owned by them or their parent or guardian and used by such person with disabilities. 
(c)  Motor vehicle tax exemption. Any motor vehicle which is owned and used by a Seymour resident with disabilities or owned by the parent or guardian of such person, which is equipped for such disabled person, is hereby eligible for exemption from the motor vehicle tax of the Town of Seymour, provided that an application for such exemption is filed with the Seymour Assessor's Office in a timely manner pursuant to the provisions of subsection (d) of this section and the motor vehicle is found by the Seymour Assessor to satisfy the criteria set forth in this section for such an exemption. 
(d)  Procedures for application. An applicant for a motor vehicle tax exemption pursuant to this ordinance shall file an application with the assessor, annually, at any time from the assessment date to within two months after the tax due date. Said application shall contain all information reasonably required by the assessor to enable him to determine whether or not the applicant and the vehicle satisfy all the requirements set forth in this section. The assessor may require the submission of such supplemental information and documentation as he may reasonably require enabling him to determine if the applicant is entitled to said tax exemption. The assessor shall determine whether the applicant is eligible for said tax exemption pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
    The assessor, in making such determination, may inspect said motor vehicle and consider the extent to which motor vehicle has been modified, the purpose for which the vehicle is being used, and the exclusivity of the use of said vehicle. Failure to file an application for said exemption annually shall result in the loss of the tax exemption, but will not preclude any applicant from making application in subsequent years. 
(e)  Effective date. The provisions of this section shall become effective for the October 1, 2002 assessment year upon approval of the Seymour's Board of Selectmen. Notwithstanding the effective date of October 1, 2002, any such previous motor vehicle tax exemption approved by the assessor for assessment years 1998 through 2001 is hereby ratified and given retroactive effect. 
(Ord. of 11-19-02(4)) 
Sec. 15-11. - Permits and licenses to be withheld from delinquent taxpayers. 
(a)  [ Conditions for non-issuance of permits and licenses; revocation. ] 
(1)  No building permit, certificate of occupancy, and/or other construction permit for improvements or changes in real property shall be issued for any real property for which there are delinquent municipal taxes, including water and sewer rates, charges and/or assessments. 
(2)  Any license or permit for a business enterprise may be revoked, and no license or permit to operate a business enterprise shall be issued, if any taxes levied by the town against personal property used in such business are delinquent and have been so delinquent for a period of not less than one year. 
(b)  [ Delinquency list; tax collector certification. ] 
(1)  The Tax Collector of the Town of Seymour shall file with the building official, health district and board of selectmen a list of all properties and property owners who are delinquent under the terms of this section in the real property taxes, personal property taxes, sewer use taxes and any municipal assessments as of August 1 and February 1 of each year. 
(2)  Before approving or renewing any building application for property which appears on the tax collector's last filed delinquency list, the building official shall request the applicant to obtain written certification from the tax collector that the delinquent taxes haven been paid in full, including all statutory interest. 
(3)  The building official may grant a building application without the payment of all delinquent taxes if he certifies, in writing, that an emergency exists affecting the health and safety of the occupants of a building or property that is delinquent in property taxes. 
(4)  Before approving or renewing any license or permit to operate a business enterprise for property, the health district shall require the applicant to obtain written certification from the tax collector that delinquent taxes have been paid in full, including all statutory interest. 
(Ord. of 7-21-15(2), §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 15-12. - Additional property tax exemption for 100 percent disabled veterans. 
(a)  Effective for the assessment year commencing October 1, 2014, and each assessment year thereafter, Seymour shall provide that, in lieu of the additional exemption prescribed under Subsection 12-81g(a), C.G.S., any person entitled to an exemption from property tax in accordance with Section 12-81(20), C.G.S., reflecting any increase made pursuant to the provisions in Section l2-62g, C.G.S., who has a disability rating of 100 percent, as determined by the United States Department of Veterans Affairs, shall be entitled to an additional exemption from such tax in an amount equal to three times the amount of the exemption provided for such person pursuant to Section 12-81(20), C.G.S., provided such person's total adjusted gross income as determined for purposes of the federal income tax, plus any other income not included in such adjusted income, excluding veterans' disability payments, individually if unmarried, or jointly with spouse if married, during the calendar year ending immediately preceding the filing of a claim for any such exemption, is not more than $21,000.00 if such person is married or not more than $18,000.00 if such person is not married. 
(b)  Any claimant who, for purposes of obtaining an exemption under this section, willfully fails to disclose all matters related thereto or with intent to defraud makes any false statement shall forfeit the right to claim such additional veterans' exemption. 
(Ord. of 7-21-15(4)) 
Sec. 15-13. - Manufacturing exemption. 
(a)  Any manufacturer claiming exemption under Section 12-81(76), C.G.S., who failed to file a claim as required, and further failed to apply for extension per Section 12-81k, C.G.S., may seek relief for such exemption with the board of selectmen provided taxpayer files a manufacturing, machinery and equipment exemption claim form with the assessor prior to meeting with the board of selectmen. 
(b)  Effective for the October 1, 2015, grand list and subsequent grand list years, the deadline to meet with the board of selectmen for such year shall be prior to May 1, following such assessment date of October 1, at their regularly scheduled meeting. Such meeting shall be public. 
(c)  Effective for the October 1, 2014, grand list only, the deadline to meet with the board of selectmen shall be prior to January 1, 2016, at their regularly scheduled meeting. Such meeting shall be public. 
(d)  The board of selectmen may grant such exemption according to criteria set by such board on a case-by-case basis. 
(e)  Final decisions by board of selectmen shall be in the minutes of such meeting and assessor shall be notified of such decision by the first selectman within ten days of such meeting. 
(f)  None of the above shall be construed to override the assessor if the assessor deems such equipment does not qualify for exemption under Section 12-81(76), C.G.S. 
(Ord. of 10-20-15(1), §§ 1-6) 
Sec. 15-14. - Debt service fund. 
(a)  Creation; purpose; intent. There is hereby created within the financial accounts of the Town of Seymour a fund known as the "debt service fund." The purpose of said fund is to account for accumulations of resources in connection with the payment of principal and interest maturing in future years. 
(b)  Disclosure statement; financial activities. The debt service fund shall disclose and report all activities of the fund at the end of each fiscal year. All financial activities of the debt service fund shall be accounted for and reported in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated for state and local governments by the government accounting standards board (GASB). 
(Ord. of 6-6-18(1)) 
Chapter 16 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Operation of motor vehicles on school grounds, § 11-15; transportation of intoxicating liquors by minors, § 11-18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic generally, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(B)(i); authority to regulate speed of vehicles, G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(B)(ii); authority restricted, G.S. § 14-162. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Definitions. 
    Whenever in this chapter the following terms are used they shall the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. 
    Alley. A public way within a block, generally giving access to the rear of lots or buildings, and not used for general traffic circulation. 
    Bicycle. Every device, propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels either of which is more than 20 inches in diameter. 
    Board of police commissioners. The duly appointed members of the board of police commissioners acting in their official capacity. 
    Crosswalk. That portion of the roadway included within the prolongation of the sidewalk lines at street intersections. 
    Driver. Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Emergency vehicle. Police vehicles, vehicles of the fire department, ambulances, vehicles carrying a state, or municipal officer or employee in response to an emergency call, and emergency vehicles of public service corporations on an emergency call. 
    Explosive. Any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and which contains any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities, or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by concussion, by percussion, or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructible effects on contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb. 
    Farm tractor. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm implement for drawing plows, mowing machines, and other implements of husbandry. 
    Improved highway. A roadway of concrete, brick, asphalt, macadam or gravel. 
    Intersection. The area embraced within the prolongation of the property lines of two or more streets which join at an angle, whether or not such streets cross. 
    Laned roadway. A street, the roadway of which is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Loading zone. The space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Merging traffic. A maneuver executed by the drivers of vehicles on converging roadways to permit simultaneous or alternate entry into the junction thereof, wherein the driver of each vehicle involved is required to adjust his vehicular speed and lateral position so as to avoid a collision with any other vehicles. 
    Metal tires. Every tire the surface of which in contact with the roadway is wholly or partially metal or other hard, nonresilient material. 
    Motorcycle. Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Motor vehicle. Every vehicle which is self-propelled, but not operated upon rails. 
    Park. To stand a vehicle whether occupied or not, for a period of time greater than is reasonably necessary for the actual loading or unloading of persons. 
    Pedestrian. Any person afoot. 
    Pneumatic tire. Every tire in which compressed air is designed to support the load. 
    Property line. The line marking the boundary between any street and lots or property abutting thereon. 
    Public building. A building used by the municipality, the county, the state or the United States government. 
    Right-of-way. The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    Road tractor. Every motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon either independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn. 
    Safety zone. That portion of a roadway reserved for the exclusive use of pedestrians, suitably marked or elevated. 
    School bus. Every motor vehicle operated by or for a public or governmental agency or by or for a private or religious organization solely for the transportation of pupils in connection with school activities. 
    Semitrailer. Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
    Sidewalk. That portion of a street between the curbline or roadway and the adjacent property line designated for pedestrian use. 
    Solid tire. Every tire of rubber or other resilient material which does not depend upon compressed air for the support of the load. 
    Street or highway. The entire width between property lines or every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
    Traffic. Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances whether singly or together while using any highway for the purpose of travel. 
    Trailer. Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying passengers or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle. 
    Truck tractor. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
    Urban district. The territory contiguous to and including any street which is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling houses situated at intervals of less than 100 feet for a distance of a quarter mile or more. 
    Vehicle. Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway except devices moving by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Yield right-of-way. When required by an official sign, means the act of granting the privilege of the immediate use of the intersecting roadway to traffic within the intersection and to vehicles approaching from the right or left, provided that when the roadway is clear the vehicle may proceed into the intersection. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 16-2. - Obedience to police. 
    Members of the police department and special police assigned to traffic duty, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, or in emergencies as public safety or convenience may require and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a policeman. It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by law, to direct or attempt to direct traffic, provided that this section shall not apply to emergency accident situations where a duly authorized officer of the law is not the scene. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-2) 
Sec. 16-3. - Signs and signals. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to disobey the instructions of any traffic sign or signal placed in view by authority of the board of police commissioners or in accordance with the laws of the state, except on direction of a police officer. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-3) 
Sec. 16-4. - Traffic-control signal legend. 
(a)  The following legend shall apply to all drivers and pedestrians. When traffic at an intersection is alternately directed to proceed and to stop by the use of signals exhibiting colored lights or lighted arrows, successively one at a time or in combination, only the colors green, red and yellow shall be used, except for special pedestrian-control signals carrying word legends, these lights shall apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians and shall indicate the following: 
(1)  Circular green alone. Vehicular traffic facing a green signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign or marking at such place prohibits either such turn or straight through movement, except that such traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles lawfully within a crosswalk or the intersection at the time such signal was exhibited; pedestrians facing the green signal, except when directed by separate pedestrian-control signals, may proceed across the highway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Yellow. Vehicular traffic facing a steady yellow signal is thereby warned that the related green movement is being terminated or that a red indication will be exhibited immediately thereafter, when vehicular traffic shall stop before entering the intersection unless so close to the intersection that a stop cannot be made in safety; pedestrians facing a steady yellow signal, except when directed by separate pedestrian-control signals, are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway before a red indication is shown and no pedestrian shall then start to cross the roadway. 
(3)  Red alone. Vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal alone shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and remain standing until the next indication is shown; pedestrians facing a steady red signal alone, except when directed by separate pedestrian-control signals, shall not enter the roadway. 
(4)  Green arrow. Vehicular traffic facing a green arrow signal, shown alone or in combination with another indication, may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow, or such other movement as is permitted by other indications shown at the same time, but such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully within the intersection. 
(5)  Pedestrian signals. Whenever special pedestrian-control signals exhibiting the words "Walk" or "Don't Walk" are in place such signals shall indicate as follows: 
a.  Walk. Pedestrians facing such signals may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles; 
b.  Don't walk. No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the walk signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the "Don't Walk" signal is showing. 
(b)  When an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic sign or signal, it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red. When a red lens is illuminated by rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection, or at a limit line when marked or, if none, then before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow. When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles facing such signal may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(c)  When lane-directions-control signals are placed over the individual lanes of a street or highway, vehicular traffic may travel in any lane over which a green arrow signal is shown, but shall not enter or travel in any lane over which a red X signal is shown. 
(d)  If a traffic-control signal, approved by the state traffic commission, is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this section shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any sign or marking the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-1) 
Sec. 16-5. - Unauthorized signs. 
    No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, nor shall any person place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway any other sign which hides from view or interferes with the movement of traffic or effectiveness of any traffic-control device or any railroad sign or signal, and no person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway any traffic or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. Any such unauthorized device is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and may be removed by any policeman. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-1) 
Sec. 16-6. - Interference with signs or signals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, move or interfere with any official traffic sign or signal. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-1) 
Sec. 16-7. - Animals or bicycles. 
    Every person riding a bicycle or an animal, or driving any animal drawing a vehicle upon any street, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except those provisions which can have no application to one riding a bicycle or driving or riding an animal, provided that, except in business districts, bicycles may be ridden on sidewalks. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-1) 
Sec. 16-8. - Riding on running boards. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, running boards or outside step of any vehicle except on municipal vehicles where required for municipal services. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-9. - Clinging to vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person on any street riding a bicycle, motorcycle or any toy vehicle to cling to or to attach himself or his vehicle to any moving motor vehicle or wagon. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-10. - Unattended animals. 
    It shall be unlawful to leave any horse or other draft animal unattended in any street without having such animal securely fastened. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-11. - Toy vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates, a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle, to go upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. This section shall not apply to bicycles. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-12. - Unattended vehicles. 
    No vehicle shall be left unattended while the motor of such vehicle is running; and no vehicle shall be left without a driver on any hill or incline unless the vehicle is secured against moving. Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle unattended upon any bridge or where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic, such officer is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of such vehicle to the nearest garage or other place of safety. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-13. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon the street in such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-14. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter regulating the movement or parking of vehicles shall not apply to the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency call, but such driver upon approaching a red or stop signal or any stop sign shall slow down as necessary for safety but may proceed cautiously past such red or stop sign or signal. At other times drivers of authorized emergency vehicles shall stop in obedience to a stop sign or signal. No driver of any authorized emergency vehicle shall assume any special privileges under the provisions of this chapter except when such vehicle is operated in response to an emergency call or in the immediate pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, or except as may otherwise be provided by the general statutes. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-1) 
Secs. 16-15-16-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION 

Sec. 16-31. - Through streets and one-way streets. 
(a)  One-way streets or alleys. It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on any street or alley designated as a one-way street or alley by regulation of the board of police commissioners in any direction other than that so designated. 
(b)  Stop streets. The driver of a vehicle shall make a complete stop in obedience to a stop sign at an intersection where a stop sign is erected at one or more entrances thereto, and shall thereupon proceed cautiously yielding to the vehicles not so obliged to stop which are within the intersection or approaching so close as to constitute an immediate hazard, unless traffic at such intersection is controlled by a police officer on duty, in which event the directions of the police officer shall be complied with. 
(c)  Posting signs. The chief of police or any other person designated by the board of police commissioners shall post or cause to be posted suitable signs for all such through streets, one-way streets or alleys, and stop intersections as have been established by the board of police commissioners acting as the traffic authority of the town, provided that if such installation shall require the use of heavy equipment the board of police commissioners shall so notify the first selectman who shall cause such signs to be erected by the street department. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-32. - "U" turns. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to make a "U" turn on any street. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-3) 
Sec. 16-33. - No left turn. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to turn left at any place when such turns are prohibited by posted sign. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-3) 
Sec. 16-34. - Fire department vehicles; fires. 
(a)  Upon the approach of a fire department vehicle, drivers of vehicles shall comply with the provisions of his chapter relating to the approach of authorized emergency vehicles. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle, other than one on official business, including police, firemen, ambulance drivers and the like to follow any fire apparatus in response to a fire alarm, closer than one block, or to park any vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped to answer a fire alarm. 
(b)  It shall be further unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive over any unprotected hose of the fire department without the consent of the fire chief or the assistant in command. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-3) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 16-35. - Speed restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle on any street not under the jurisdiction of the state, in an urban district within the town at a speed in excess of 30 miles per hour, or in an alley at a speed in excess of 15 miles per hour, or in a school zone in excess of 20 miles per hour. 
(b)  The board of police commissioners shall post appropriate signs as provided in section 16-31(c); provided further that the speed of all vehicles, having two or more solid tires shall not exceed ten miles per hour. 
(c)  The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the applicable maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway or when special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or other traffic by reason of weather or highway conditions; and speed shall be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle on or entering the highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-36. - Special speed limit while passing schools. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of 20 miles per hour while passing a school zone. School zones shall be marked by a posted sign marked "School Zone." 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-37. - Operation of vehicles on approach of authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle, when the driver is giving audible sign by siren, or bell, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to the right-hand edge or curb of the highway clear of any intersection and shall stop or remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  This section shall not operate to relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-38. - One-way roadways and rotary traffic islands. 
(a)  Upon a roadway designated and signposted for one-way traffic a vehicle shall be driven only in the direction designated. 
(b)  A vehicle passing around a rotary traffic island shall be driven only on the right of such island. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-39. - Funeral processions to be identified. 
    A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified by having the lights of each vehicle lighted. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-40. - Drivers in a procession. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as closely as practical and safe. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-41. - Driving through funeral or other procession. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in section 16-39. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Secs. 16-42-16-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Parking authorities, G.S. § 7-202 et seq.; creation, G.S. § 7-203; powers, G.S. § 7-204; financing of city parking authority, G.S. § 7-205; revenue bonds of city parking authority, G.S. § 7-206; rates and charges of municipal parking authority, G.S. § 7-207; parking vehicles, G.S. § 14-251; parking to obstruct driveways, G.S. § 14-252. 

Sec. 16-61. - Parking authority-Created. 
    Pursuant to section 7-203 of the general statutes there is hereby created a parking authority which shall be known as the Seymour Parking Authority. 
(Code 1961, § 18-1) 
Sec. 16-62. - Same-Membership; terms; compensation; organization; records. 
(a)  The parking authority shall consist of five members appointed by the first selectman, not more than three of whom shall be of the same political party. Those first appointed shall be designated to serve for one, two, three, four and five years respectively; and thereafter a member shall be appointed annually to serve for five years, except that any vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(b)  The parking authority shall select from among its members a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. The members of the authority shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for necessary expenses. 
(c)  No action of the parking authority shall be valid unless authorized by a vote of the majority of its members. 
(d)  The parking authority shall maintain proper accounting and financial records and shall make an annual report to the first selectman. 
(Code 1961, § 18-2) 
Sec. 16-63. - Same-Powers. 
    The parking authority shall have the powers mandated as obligatory by the state general statutes. 
(Code 1961, § 18-2.1) 
Sec. 16-64. - No parking places. 
    At any time it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a policeman or traffic-control device: 
(1)  In any intersection; 
(2)  In a crosswalk; 
(3)  Upon any bridge or the approach thereto; 
(4)  Within 25 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station; 
(5)  On any sidewalk; 
(6)  At any place where official signs prohibit parking; 
(7)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-5) 
Sec. 16-65. - Alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, an no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-5) 
Sec. 16-66. - Cab and bus stands. 
    No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by posted sign as a cab stand; and no vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-5) 
Sec. 16-67. - Time limit parking. 
(a)  Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a longer consecutive period of time than that designated in any area designated by regulation of the board of police commissioners as a limited parking area and so marked. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be parked on a public highway between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. during the months of December, January, February and March. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-5) 
Sec. 16-68. - Parking motor vehicles on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property without the consent of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-5) 
Sec. 16-69. - Vehicles for sale. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-4) 
Sec. 16-70. - Parking regulation attendants. 
(a)  The Seymour Parking Authority is hereby authorized to employ up to three parking regulation attendants who shall hold office during periods of satisfactory performance and whose duties shall be as hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  Parking regulation attendants are empowered to issue violation notices (tickets) on forms provided by the police department for all motor vehicle violations of vehicles parked upon business district streets or in business district parking lots in the town, in violation of the general statutes, the Code of Ordinances and regulations of the Seymour Parking Authority. 
(c)  Attendants shall serve under the direction of the chief of police who shall prescribe the hours of employment and direct the specific duties to be performed by parking regulation attendants. 
(d)  Parking regulation attendants shall receive such compensation as shall be duly authorized by the Seymour Parking Authority. 
(Code 1961, § 13-A-9; Ord. of 2-1-83, §§ 1-4; Ord. of 4-16-91) 
Sec. 16-71. - Business district parking. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: 
    Business district streets. For purposes of this subsection, the business district streets in the town shall include the following: Main Street, Broad Street, River Street, Bank Street from street numbers 1 through 141, North Main Street from Bank Street to Main Street, Wakeley Street, First Street, and DeForest Street. 
    Business district parking lots. The parking lot areas located on Wakeley Street, Franklin Street, and the leased portions of the Strand Theater parking lot, located at the corner of North Main and Main Streets and the parking lot on Lower Main Street at the intersection of Broad Street. 
(b)  Business district street parking. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle or to permit a vehicle to remain parked in one location on any business district street for a period longer than two hours between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, inclusive, except as may be otherwise posted in designated areas approved by the Seymour Parking Authority. This restriction shall not apply to Sundays and the legal observances of the following holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. Any vehicle parked for a period of longer than two hours on a business district street may be fined successively at intervals not less than two hours apart. 
(c)  Business district parking in parking lots. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle or to permit a vehicle to remain parked in any business district parking lot between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. Monday through Friday, inclusive, without displaying an approved parking permit sticker for the particular parking lot wherein the vehicle is parked issued to the owner or driver of the vehicle by the Seymour Parking Authority. The parking permit sticker shall be affixed on the inside of the vehicle's front windshield at the bottom corner of the passenger side in such a manner that a parking attendant or police officer may easily view the sticker at a distance when standing in back of the vehicle. 
(2)  An application for a parking permit shall be made at the police department. If an application is approve, a parking permit sticker will be issued to the applicant. Applications will be approved or denied by the Seymour Parking Authority or by whomever the Seymour Parking Authority may designate to do so. Priority for such permits will be given to the owners and employees of businesses located in the business district and residents living within the business district. 
(3)  An annual fee shall be charged by the Seymour Parking Authority for the issuance or renewal of a parking permit. All parking permits shall expire and are subject to renewal on June thirtieth of each year. The fee shall be $10.00. If any parking permit is issued between December 31st and June 30th, the parking permit fee shall be $5.00 for the period from the time of issuance through June thirtieth. 
(4)  A parking permit sticker shall display a parking permit number and may be used only on the vehicle for which it was issued. A maximum of two parking permit stickers for two motor vehicles may be issued to each applicant. However, the individual to whom a permit has been issued may be issued a replacement sticker for another vehicle without paying an additional fee, if the previously issued sticker is surrendered, in order to transfer the permit to another vehicle owned or driven by the applicant upon completing the appropriate form or forms at the police department. If the previously issued parking permit sticker is not surrendered, a fee for a new parking permit sticker will be charged. 
(5)  Parking permit stickers are not transferable and cannot be used on any vehicle other than the vehicle for which the permit was issued. 
(6)  The Seymour Parking Authority, or whomever they designate to approve or deny applications for parking permits, may issue parking permit stickers to applicants with specific restrictions.
